Article: 2020: On a Knife’s Edge?
Title: 2020: On a Knife’s Edge?
Author: Santosh Desai
Description: Talk about a cliff-hanger finish. 2019 has ended in turmoil. A host of questions and possibilities have been thrown by the events of this year, with variables multiplying as the year dragged its dying carcass to the finish line. How will the CAA/NRC/NPR issue pan out? Will the government will be able to ram its agenda through or will it retreat to fight another day? Will more decisive steps be taken on the journey to a full-fledged Hindu Rashtra? Will the new-found voice of protest that has sprung up all over the country be able to convert itself into something more lasting and meaningful? Will the judiciary intervene decisively or will run shy of confronting thorny issues? What will happen to the economy? Will the government begin to give it the priority it so badly needs? Will the media rediscover its spine? Barring the last question, the answer to which is a foregone conclusion, all the other questions have no clear answers. In many ways, 2019 was the first year when the BJP government truly acted like a BJP government. Having perhaps decided that the first year of its term gave it the best opportunity to bring about the changes it truly desired, it has gone about executing its cultural agenda with speed and great resolve. The criminalisation of Triple Talaq, the virtual abrogation of Article 370 in Kashmir, and the passing of the CAA are all pieces that fit together and outline a clear trajectory of its intentions. If one could extrapolate from its current path, it would not be too difficult to foresee its script for 2020. The NPR/NRC, the Uniform Civil Code and the construction of the Ram Janmabhoomi temple are some of the other likely milestones.  In following this path, it has simultaneously shown a level of disregard for the state of the economy that is difficult to understand. Barring a few superficial moves, it has allowed the economy to drift into a state of decline, and made its task that much harder for the rest of its term. Given that a lot of Mr Modi’s personal cachet has been built on the back of his reputation as an active agent of development, this disinterest in the economy has been particularly distressing for business, the constituency most optimistic about his tenure at one time. If the government’s disproportionate focus on its cultural agenda to the detriment of the economy has been a surprise, so has the scale and intensity of the protests that have sprung up all over the country. In the past, none of the government’s actions have been seriously challenged. The large mandate enjoyed by the government coupled with the absence of any meaningful opposition had created a sense that it could do whatever it wanted. The profile of the people protesting went well beyond the usual smattering of well-meaning activists, and cut across class, town size and significantly religion. This was not a Muslim-only protest movement, and the active leadership of the young, both in several towns as well as in campuses across the country, was again something that was against the run of play.  The government’s response has been two-fold. On the ground, it has come down heavily on the protests, particularly in Muslim-dominated areas, while on air it has made vague and not entirely comprehensible sounds suggesting a backdown. Police action has often been brutal and any number of videos documenting this are doing the rounds. It is clear that the police have been given the mandate to send a message and they are doing just that. Allegations of violence from the protestors’ side may well have a grain of truth in them, but the police response has been in line with what Yogi Adityanath termed as a desire for ‘revenge’. Besides, the state has discovered a new-found respect for public property, one that has been sorely in the absence in previous agitations.  The way forward looks murky. If the BJP believes that the protests will die down in a while and that it can go ahead with its plans without too much disruption, then it may be in for a surprise. The stakes here are deeply asymmetrical. For one side it is a matter of existence and freedom and for the other, underlining of a symbolic distinction. Even if the protests were to become quieter, when the actual NRC is carried out, the situation is almost certain to become highly volatile. Also, regional parties in different states, even if they happen to be BJP allies, have not shown the appetite for handling the kind of fallout that is inevitable.  On the other hand, it is possible that the NRC was always a red herring. Its purpose was never to be implemented but to be used as a polarising agent. If that is the case, then that plan might well work. At some stage sustained protests by Muslims will in all likelihood invite a reaction, particularly in small town North India. But unlike the earlier instances where the polarisation was largely of a controlled nature, this time around, there are chances that it will become a raging fire that could consume the country. There are signs that there is a New India, and it might not look like what the ruling party might have wished for.  2020 is set up intriguingly, menacingly even. The gradual stifling of democratic institutions that has been in evidence over the last many years might reach a decisive point. The subjugation of the Muslim in India might become more official. The space for disagreement and dissent might shrink even more. Alternatively, the countervailing spirit of resistance might halt the government in its tracks. More practically, its lack of success in state politics and its inability to carry state governments along might slow down the government’s plans to push ahead with its cultural agenda. 2020 will determine the future direction this country will take. One way or another.  Facebook Twitter Linkedin Email Top Comment Narendra M. Apte 454 days ago 1. This is an interesting view on the year gone by and what to expect from 2020. When would these intellectuals and politicians look at the problems of economy as opportunity to set things in order? Is someone enjoying the economic slowdown? 3. I wish leaders of Congress and other non-BJP parties accept this fact and offer a hand of cooperation to NDA government. I will go a step further and say that the opposition parties should demand implementation of much-needed fiscal/economic, administration, judicial system, police administration and election law reforms so that India can move forward.... Article: Gujarat’s Muslim rehab sites: The cruelty within
Title: Gujarat’s Muslim rehab sites: The cruelty within
Author: Rajiv Shah
Description: It was early 1970s, when I was sought to be navigated into Marxism-Leninism by my then “political mentor” and a senior student colleague, Sohail Hashmi. A total novice in politics, I was doing bachelors in English at Kirori Mal College, Delhi University, while he was in human geography. Impressed by his argumentative power, I would often look upon Hashmi – formerly very active with CPM, but now more into culture, heritage, and things similar – as one of those who would, very soon, trigger  a proletarian revolution in India, like Lenin and his colleagues did in Russia! While I don’t care to remember most of what Hashmi had taught me (perhaps he himself would have unlearned some of it), I still recall a seemingly academic argument he had advanced in order to prove how Hindus and Muslims faced similar exploitation. This is what he told me, roughly: “Make a graph and draw two separate lines of class exploitation – one for Hindus, another for Muslims. You would find that both Hindu and Muslim working classes suffer similarly. There is no point in saying that the Muslim working classes face a higher degree of exploitation than their Hindu counterparts.” Presumably, he was referring to his immediate rivals in the non-CPM Left, particularly CPI and left-wing sections of the Congress, who would look at minorities as a homogenous group needing a higher degree of help than Hindus. I don’t know if Hashmi sticks to his view now – it was, possibly, born out of the CPM-sponsored study circles for student activists of the Students Federation of India, then very active in Delhi University. Maybe it is for scholars to ascertain whether what Hashmi had told me holds true and how, but I was reminded of he told me while going through a just-released book, “Creating Spaces: Nurturing Leadership”, authored by Dr Uma Ramaswamy, released on January 28 at an Ahmedabad function presided over by well-known left-wing rural journalist P Sainath. While the book tells the story of 30-year-old journey of Janvikas, an Ahmedabad-based non-government organization, most of which I have known from close quarters, including its work among the rehabilitation colonies set up following the 2002 Gujarat riots, what struck me most was how the poorer sections who live in in these colonies suffer at the hands of the Muslim elite, and also how Muslim women are at the receiving end within the community. Calling those who were displaced due to riots (claimed to be 2 lakh in 2002, down to 50,000 now) internally-displaced persons (IDPs), a term coined by United Nations to identify those displaced as a result of violent social strife, the book quotes Hofeza Ujjaini, who is coordinating Janvikas’ work among Gujarat’s 69 rehabilitation sites, to say, “Currently, the most pressing issue of IDPs is housing ownership. Even religious trusts who earlier gave lands for housing are now reluctant to give housing rights. What is now being assured are their residential rights and not ownership rights which has brought much insecurity in the communities.” A revealing statement, it coincides with an unpublished 2016 paper I had read recently. This paper makes an astounding revelation:  Even 14 years after the communal flare-up in Gujarat, about 3,000 families living in these rehabilitation colonies, formed mostly by Muslim NGOs, faced eviction. The paper, titled “Failing Act of Benevolence”, alleges, “These organizations have turned their backs on the people, refusing to entertain them”, adding, they are threatening them of eviction “if they raise their voice.” It adds, at certain places, the committees formed to overlook the welfare of the colonies have “turned hostile to the displaced people and have threatened the residents about losing their homes if they protested unnecessarily.” The paper reports, “Out of the 83 colonies, only in 17 the houses are in the name of the residents. Availing, passport, pan card and aadhaar card becomes difficult for these residents as they do not have any document that certifies them as residents of these areas.” The paper – authored by Johanna Lokhande in association with Ujjaini –the organizations which have “turned their back” on the residents are some well-known all-India Islamic bodies and Muslim trusts operating from Hyderabad, Mumbai and Vadodara. Some of these are supported by builders. A 2015 Gujarati language research work titled “Muslim Ghettoisation: Ek Karun Dastan” by Gujarat Vidyapeeth scholar Dr Damini Shah made a somewhat similar observation, saying the ghettoisation of Muslims following the 2002 Gujarat riots has led to a “shocking rise in religious obscurantism in the Muslim colonies, most of which were set up by Islamic NGOs in order to provide security to the riot victims.” Shah found that the dozen resettlement colonies she surveyed had “imposing mosques and madrasas attached to them, with all the necessary facilities”, in sharp contrast to the poor housing facilities in which the resettled Muslims live in sub-human conditions. She quotes maulvis of the mosques as saying that “the Muslims had to suffer in the 2002 riots they failed to properly pray to the Allah.” The rise of obscurantism, obviously, leads to further oppression of women – another issue highlighted by Ramaswamy in the book. Even as claiming that Janvikas, post-Godhra, has helped women come out of their homes, join protests, and capacitated them, leading to a situation where a “critical mass of women leaders” have emerged, the book quotes one Nazima Pathan as saying, “Women who have come from different villages have lost a lot. Families that once lived in comfort are now confined in tiny settlements with no employment opportunities, resulting in domestic conflicts.” Another woman, Janisar Shaikh, one of the “leaders”, says, while some women have become more vocal, things “should pick up momentum”, noting, “I see many elderly women who are single and deserted coming for help.” Reporting formation of “triple talaq committees” to fight the evil practice, the book says, Mahila Samajik Nyay Manch (MSNM), which works among the rehabilitation colonies in Aravalli and Sabarkantha districts, is faced with “the most important issue” women face – “domestic violence, and most importantly address the complex issue of ‘triple talaq’ that has been besieging women.” In fact, according to MSNM, says the book, “20 percent of women in these districts are made single because of ‘triple talaq’,” adding, “While violence against women has become an integral dimension of women’s lives across India, Muslim women are doubly burdened by the custom of ‘triple talaq’ that their personal law allows.” Though I am not aware of any in-depth study about on Muslim women in Gujarat, a 2011 study by London-based group, Minority Rights Group International, London, has found similar “double burden” among Gujarat’s Dalit women. It says, the Dalit woman  “is at risk of becoming a victim of violence perpetrated by an outsider, but even more frequently by a member of her own community.”, adding, “She is at risk of becoming a victim of an unnatural death due to family discord. And she is at risk of turning to the criminal justice system for protection but finding little support and even less justice.” The study, carried out with the help of well-known Dalit rights NGO Navsarjan Trust, records a total of 704 crimes against Dalit women by Dalits, of which 416 were cruelty by In-laws and 31 were Dowry Act crimes. Further, it adds, there were 288 crimes on Dalit women by Dalits who are not family members (grievous and non-grievous). The 288 crimes included 4 murders, 4 attempted murders, 12 rapes, 39 acts of outraging modesty and 16 cases of abetment to suicide. Article: Talaq isn’t the problem: Many women are happy to break free from marriage
Title: Talaq isn’t the problem: Many women are happy to break free from marriage
Author: TOI Edit
Description: When the Supreme Court invalidated triple talaq, it was taking away the legal status of a practice where Muslim women could be divorced and rendered homeless in an instant. Divorce, by itself, is not a problem – men and women are better off if they can easily free themselves from an unwanted or burdensome marriage. It is the terms of parting that must be fair, in terms of material security. Triple talaq is instant, unilateral male repudiation leaving no room for negotiation or reconciliation. Outlawed in 22 Muslim-majority nations, it now has no legal force in India. It is true that social practices are not easy to extinguish by law (as the persistence of dowry, child marriage and domestic violence make clear), but what would Parliament achieve with a bill criminalising what is already illegal? It might serve to intimidate Muslim men but it doesn’t serve Muslim women’s welfare to have an estranged spouse in jail for three years, cutting off all support from him anyway. Criminalising may even be counterproductive, making women reluctant to report a pronouncement of triple talaq. Muslim marriage is a civil contract, its dissolution should be civil too. In all of today’s din there’s also a danger of the tired and defeated image of divorced women getting entrenched. Quite to the contrary divorce can be liberating, and marriage something from which women are thrilled to break free. To be happily unmarried. Article: Hope is very much a strategy
Title: Hope is very much a strategy
Author: Economic Times
Description: By: M Muneer Abraham Lincoln must be turning in his grave for not taking into consideration us Indians when he delivered those famous lines, “You can fool all the people some of the time and some of the people all the time, but you cannot fool all the people all the time.” For, what has the political class been doing to us since Independence? Hope. It is a powerful emotion that can dramatically influence human behaviour. It is almost like faith, a confident trust in someone or something. It makes us aspire for more — like in Bollywood movies — for a better (even if implausible) future and drives us to dream and act. Hope is a fabulous marketable commodity. It’s not a buzzword. It’s a real feeling of possibilities. People look towards politicians for hope, as well as to countries, social groups, families and religion. Hope is not strategy is what experts say. But hope as a positioning strategy works eternally and is a trillion-dollar industry. Take the key positioning of most products and services. Soaps, shampoos, cosmetics, B-schools, lifestyle products, politicians. Remember the promises of roti, kapda aur makaan? Or the recent bijli-paani? Most leaders, once elected, simply forget about fulfilling that hope. Prime Minister Narendra Modi hasn’t. He launched the demonetisation drivefor a seemingly impossible mission, with less-than-optimal execution: to rid the country of black money. Modi found a connection with the masses, for whom the idea of the rich suffering was hitched to a brand new hope. And the reports of CEOs attributing poor results to demonetisation actually helped reinforce that hope. That the Opposition failed to bust the myth of the ‘rich are miserable’ aggravated their failure in UP. Modi went further to achieve another impossibility: the abolition of beacons on official cars, the symbolism of VIP-ness. The strategic framework for managing hope has delivered results. Show the overall possibilities first. Follow them with the possibilities in the individual, and finally those in the process. Then comes the second track: of aggrandising this craving, amplifying hope. This can be more tricky. What this involves is increasing the perceived importance of the outcome, and increasing the degree of its association with an acclamatory goal. It is worth looking at cow vigilantism or the triple talaq controversy through this lens. Much more than just hot air It may be to divert attention from the core issues — growing unemployment, deteriorating security, escalating cost of living, troubling non-performing assets, and poor execution of many flagship projects —so that the ‘craving’ gets boosted. Going by the strategic framework, Modi is likely to announce new schemes and mechanisms to reverse the effects. He will even deliver some promises to keep the hopes alive for the rest of his term as prime minister. By following the two tracks, Modi will continue to retain the loyalty created via hope. Because of this, many will forgive below-expected performance. People will ignore, or rationalise, average-to-poor performance when hopes are high in a brand, person or outcome. More importantly, they need less persuasion then to be convinced further. Herein lies the Catch-22 for the Opposition: damned if they oppose, damned if they don’t. The Opposition needs a better strategy than to steal the hope platform. Secular? Nah. Anti-Modi rhetoric? Nope. Demolishing the claims of the growth agenda? Maybe for diluting the hope platform, but not to bring in new hopes. Instead of applying Newton’s third law to every NDA action, they should focus on the core ones driving optimismand try and demolish them. Without bringing disdain, they will not be able to build new hopes. Figurefudging issues is something that will find currency with the business community. A grand alliance is also unlikely to bring any new hope, as it is just a coalition of the same perceived corrupt and feudal set. Does the Opposition have a clear vision that enhances hope? None was visible in the silence on cow vigilantism, anti-Muslim or Dalit outbreaks, triple talaq and so on. Instead, it could embrace a disruptive strategy that will damage the NDA’s hope strategy. There are three key traits that are the hallmarks of people who can instil hope in others: one, caring deeply about, and working for, people; two, having the focus on what is possible and matters most to people; three, speaking from the heart, a.k.a. ‘mann ki baat’. Modi ticks all these boxes. Article: ‘If BJP believes in parliamentary democracy, it should offer leader of opposition position to the single largest party’
Title: ‘If BJP believes in parliamentary democracy, it should offer leader of opposition position to the single largest party’
Author: Swati Mathur
Description: Revolutionary Socialist Party’s NK Premachandran has been appointed to Lok Sabha Speaker’s panel despite being his party’s only parliamentarian, a unique distinction. He speaks to Swati Mathur about it and the challenges faced by Congress, his political ally in Kerala: You are the first from a single-member party to be appointed to the Speaker’s panel. How did that happen? I was surprised when the Speaker asked me whether I was interested in chairing the House. I immediately responded in the affirmative because it is a big recognition, especially as it is not mandatory. Normally, parties are chosen on the basis of their strength and their nominees are approved by the Speaker. In my case, it was a suo motu decision on consideration of merit. I am grateful to the Speaker for recognising my contribution to the 16th Lok Sabha. I feel proud about being recognised for being a good parliamentarian. You have been an extremely active member of the Lok Sabha, making interventions and introducing amendments. I moved more than 2,000 amendments. However, none of them were accepted. That is why, in my opening speech in Parliament in the 17th Lok Sabha, in the PM’s presence, I said that none of the amendments moved by opposition members were being accepted by the government. This practice must change. In the Kerala state legislative assembly, where I was minister, if a constructive suggestion came from the opposition, it was weaved in. That is the purpose of making these rules. Why else should a Bill be put to discussion? Unfortunately, parliamentary practices don’t follow this. Here, we (opposition) only move amendments and the government kills them. A lot of new MPs look up to you for help on parliamentary procedures. I believe if you know the rules and procedures, the constitutional provisions, and conventions and precedents of the House, you will get ample chance to intervene. Do you think the leadership crisis in Congress is affecting UPA floor strategy in Parliament? Congress is in a transition period because Rahul Gandhi has resigned and a new leadership has to emerge. I feel they will emerge from this. Rahul, even though he is not holding the office of Congress president, has a say in Congress and he is the unanimously accepted leader of Congress from the grassroots level to the top. So, even though someone else is president, Rahul can do a lot of things. According to me, a collective leadership should emerge to fight a party (BJP) that has the backing of the Sangh Parivar, and a formidable and most modern political management. Also, my suggestion is that all secular democratic parties should have a common platform and good floor coordination on political issues. For this, Congress has to take the initiative. Doesn’t not staking claim to the post of leader of opposition (LoP) represent a lost opportunity for the opposition? The LoP post comes with some privileges and rights. If the LoP stands, the Speaker must give her a chance as per convention. The LoP represents the entire opposition. It is not the same as the Congress floor leader standing up for a chance to speak. There is no legal bar that says a certain number of MPs are needed to get the LoP post. In the past, CPM’s AK Gopalan was LoP when the party had very limited numbers. It only needs a direction by the Speaker. If BJP believes in parliamentary democracy and in an effective and active opposition, it should offer the LoP position to the single largest party. What is the harm in doing this? In democracy, the role of opposition is critical in making the government accountable to people. Is that opportunity closed now? I don’t think so. It can still be done. There is no time frame that governs the appointment of LoP. The LoP can be recognised at any time. All it needs is an announcement. Why did you recently move a private member’s Bill on Sabarimala? Sabarimala deals with the traditional faith of people in Kerala. Almost everyone who follows the faith did not accept the Supreme Court verdict on Sabarimala. During Lok Sabha elections, BJP president Amit Shah and other leaders said they would go to any extent to protect the rights of Ayyappa devotees. Why then are they not legislating on the subject now? In the case of prevention of atrocities against scheduled castes and tribes, government filed a review petition in SC. Even in the Triple Talaq Bill, government issued three ordinances on the dissenting judge’s view. The majority judgment did not say a law was needed but the government relied on one dissenting opinion to issue three ordinances. Sabarimala too needs a legislation. As a part of UDF (United Democratic Front), we had a defined position on the Sabarimala that we stand with the devotees. That is why I moved the private member’s Bill. Article: Is the law banning ‘Triple Talaq’ a move in the right direction?
Title: Is the law banning ‘Triple Talaq’ a move in the right direction?
Author: Shikha Purohit
Description: Last year, the Indian Parliament enacted a law banning instant Triple Talaq which was termed as historic by the government. It was celebrated as a giant move towards equality for Muslim women claiming that it ended inequality and indignity perpetrated against them by male authoritarianism. But does the law actually serve the purpose it was enacted for?  The answer is an emphatic ‘No’. In the journey towards ensuring equal rights for women, this law is a move in the wrong direction. It is an archaic law which focuses primarily on protecting marriage for protecting the rights of women. Whereas the truth is that several times, and in cases involving instant Triple Talaq most of the times, marriage works as an instrumentality for inflicting discrimination against women. The law is based solely on the notion that women’s rights can be ensured only by preserving the wedlock she is tied in, however detrimental it may be to her life and personality.  Continuance of a marital relationship devoid of affection and mutual respect harms a woman many times more than its unusual disruption. A man who arbitrarily and unilaterally breaks a marriage simply by pronouncing three words of Talaq for reasons ranging from some ridiculous ones like not cooking proper food to some despicable ones like giving birth to a girl child, clearly has no respect for his wife and to force her to remain in a wedlock with him in violation of her dignity. But still, women are reluctant to move out of such disgraceful relationship as they fear the financial insecurity and lack of societal support which usually flow from it. While men easily come out of a relation without any stigma attached to them, on the other hand, women have to undergo a hefty emotional and psychological trauma.  Only a law addressing the underlying factors forcing women to continue in such marriages can suffice the purpose of achieving equality for Muslim women. Unfortunately, the present law fails on this count. Equality cannot be attained merely by prohibiting Talaq-e-Biddat. To get it we need a law which provides for equal rights of divorce to Muslim women. Instead of criminalizing triple talaq the government should have amended the Muslim Women Divorce Act, 1939 and provided that pronouncement of Talaq in one breath without following the Quranic procedure of reconciliation would amount to cruelty and the wife would have the right to seek divorce on this ground. Such provision would have laid the choice in wife’s hand either to condone her husband’s act or to take judicial recourse to get rid of him.  Facebook Twitter Linkedin Email Top Comment Bala Srinivasan 416 days ago What a stupid question even to CONTEMPLATE."TRIPLE"Talaq was a 'DEMEANING"and mysogynistic treatment of muslim women with cavalier unrepentant way of terminating a marriage. Article: Don’t write off BJP in Uttar Pradesh’s game of thrones
Title: Don’t write off BJP in Uttar Pradesh’s game of thrones
Author: Sanjeev Singh
Description: With just two of the seven phases of polling to go in the Uttar Pradesh assembly elections, it remains a challenge for any political pundit to pick a clear winner. After chief minister Akhilesh Yadav emerged as the undisputed leader of Samajwadi Party and tied up with Congress, he appeared to have had an edge with two weeks to go before the polls. Has Akhilesh been able to ward off anti-incumbency and hold on to that advantage? Or is it the grossly under-estimated BSP that is emerging as the dark horse? As per reports from various journalists and keen election observers, the surprise package has been BJP which has somehow managed to stay in the race for top honours. BJP’s campaign looked jaded just before the first phase of polling on February 11 as reports of the dominant Jat community siding with Chaudhary Ajit Singh’s Rashtriya Lok Dal (RLD) started appearing. This phase was crucial to BJP’s scheme of things as they had done exceedingly well in the region during the 2014 general election. After the 2013 Muzaffarnagar riots, Jats had sided with BJP but the mood seemed to have changed in the past few weeks. BJP president Amit Shah held last-minute closed door meetings to appease Jat leaders. Party workers led a massive door-to-door campaign to regain lost ground despite being on a sticky wicket in the first two phases of polling in western UP. BJP seems to have done well in third and fourth phases especially in urban areas and cities like Lucknow, Kanpur and Allahabad. UP elections: Mandir, triple talaq and exodus in BJP’s manifesto https://t.co/NTqvuEm1T2 pic.twitter.com/Oo1zpo9AXf — Times of India (@timesofindia) January 29, 2017 So what is working in favour of BJP on the ground? The party’s strategy to aggressively woo non-Yadav OBCs and non-Jatav Dalits could be turning beneficial for BJP. Let’s talk about OBC politics in the state and imagine a scenario in a particular constituency where non-Yadav OBCs are unhappy with SP candidate. It is then that the chance of non-Yadav OBCs voting for BJP to register their protest becomes high. It is almost inconceivable for SP supporters to vote for BSP but they are not averse to voting for BJP. One can safely draw a similar correlation between non-Jatav BSP supporters who are unhappy with BSP candidates as well. 160 crorepatis, 126 with criminal cases in 6th phase of UP Polls https://t.co/6C7iVH410U#StatePolls pic.twitter.com/OX3sSIE5f6 — Times of India (@timesofindia) March 2, 2017 BJP has also stitched crucial alliances with smaller parties like the Kurmi based Apna Dal and Rajbhar dominated Suheldev Bharatiya Samaj Party (SBSP). The consolidation of Rajbhar votes can significantly tilt the balance in favour of BJP and its allies in over 50 of the 89 seats that will go polls in the last two phases. This could effectively put BJP in the driver’s seat in the race for Lucknow. Article: Triple talaq bill: The first step towards upliftment of Muslim women
Title: Triple talaq bill: The first step towards upliftment of Muslim women
Author: Arshia Malik
Description: The triple talaq bill is facing stiff resistance in the Indian Parliament both on technical and Constitutional grounds. The All India Muslim Personal Law Board (AIMPLB) is already getting ready to contest it if it is passed. At the core of this national debate, polarisation and politics is Shaira Bano, the woman who took on the Muslim Personal Law by the horns and decided to seek justice, with a monumental judgement being awarded in her favour against the unfair practice of talaq-e-bidat (instant talaq). The day the judgement came out, I picked up the phone to call my mother that day. We have not had an easy relationship for the greater part of my life, her having suffered a lot in a patriarchal setup on account of the rebellious me. But time has a way of settling down conflicts, whether personal or political and so there is an effort on her part to understand her grandchild and his upbringing, while all I have is compassion, patience and understanding. I am hoping the forgiveness is from her side as well, as it is from mine; for the deep wounds, we inflicted on each other’s psyche. Mama likes to keep abreast of the happenings in the Muslim world, reconciling it with what she was taught, what she believes in and what she objects to. It is not easy to negotiate the usual pitfalls of her hatred for the Jews (Yahoodi), the Shias and the deep dislike for the kuffar (Hindus and everyone else who is not from the Muslim faith). It can be testing for my patience and calm when her conditioning manifests itself in the long tirades. But there is one common ground where she is an ally of mine – progressive Islam and reform. A woman who, having suffered the abandonment of our father for 18 years, and not being a working woman herself (he forbade her to work when the opportunity presented itself in a Government Emporium), she was on fire and ice for the two years that I stayed home to breast feed my only child. I had chosen to leave my teaching job since private jobs were unregulated in those days and the only option for pregnant women was either to forgo their pay for the leave taken or resign. She was the one who brought me the application form of a new CBSE school which had started in the Valley, and she had many sleepless nights until my career relaunched. She is the first person to understand what was happening with Shaira and as I revealed the case to her over the months, her enthusiasm piqued and she started rooting for her with a ferociousness I hadn’t seen in decades. There were tears, reminiscences, sighs, and shrugs in our conversations, and I knew she had somehow associated herself with the case as if she was fighting her own injustice of long ago. In the politicisation and media circus of the bill being presented, many often forget the individuals at the heart of it. The way I observe the reactions within the Muslim community to it, or outside, from the Left, the Liberal circles, the orthodox, the centrists and so on, many don’t have the faintest idea of the kind of resistance Muslims have for reform. The triple talaq bill is just one aspect of sharia law which governs Indian Muslims through the Muslim Personal Law under the “secular” Constitution of India. Of course, things are a bit more complicated for Kashmiri women since we are governed by the Ranbir Penal Code (RPC) as well, because of the Special Status accorded to us due to Article 370. What is revolutionary about the case being tried in court is that Muslim women, both the educated – aware and the unaware ones, the representative Muslim women groups and the fissures / conflicting voices within them, as well as the scores of women whom they claim to lead, are a part of this whole discourse challenging the mullahs and their interpretation and diktats of our religion. Whether they are on social media, or not, the ordinary Muslim woman seeing Shaira Bano, Hadiya and Ishrat Jahan speak up their minds are getting exposed to something that has not been visible in our culture for a long time and was quashed whenever it made its presence felt – dissent. From Rabia of Basra to reformers in the West to these Eastern women, critical thinking and questioning, freedom of expression and dissent are not exactly encouraged. The men notwithstanding, it is the women themselves (those who carry water for Islamists) who will be the first to quash any rebellion, non-conformity, and critical stance, ones like my mother. All those years ago she preferred breaking her daughter’s will and shatter her self-esteem than trust her own blood and just listen. Like my mother, these women (outnumbering learned ones, articulate ones, moderate ones, aware ones) who just recite the text, without meaning, gulp in their social conditioning without question (the hatred for the Shia/Jews/kuffar) and resist any critical thinking free thinkers among them for fear of ostracism, and the embedded honour culture (badnaami, izzat, stigma) that debilitates any networking. Even when these simple women undergo injustice, they never leave their faith, still trust the elders of the community, the Mohalla Committees (all men on the panels seldom women), and respect the mullah/imam / pir with a reverence bordering on the schizoid. It is these women who expect their faith to deliver justice to them everytime a man transgresses; these women know the Prophet’s last sermon by heart wherein he reiterated and advised the men to respect and take care of the women, and are ready to exercise their rights under whatever laws the Islamic jurisprudence decrees. Of course, there are reformers who have issues with unjust laws, which have lost their applications with time and under the practice/ culture of “Ijtihad” (striving, endeavour) they seek to change Islamic practices to more progressive ones. All this within the ambit of Constitutions, faith, culture, courts, legislation and grass root level activism. It can’t get any more democratic than this. Yes, democracy has loopholes and considering it is more like majoritarian politics, the zeal of the BJP to pass the law without discussion has not gone unnoticed. The Muslim groups will contest it and the whole discourse will move forward with its glitches, hiccups and hitches. What is important for my mother (who never got any maintenance money for those 18 years and had to rely on the goodwill of her brothers and their wives) and me (we sisters decided that the best thing was to study and become financially independent, and repay the charity of uncles) is that she is coming around to see how her faith can be misused by misogynistic mullahs, to apologise for non-payment of alimony, abandonment due to having given birth to daughters, etc all because of the lop-sided representation in jurisprudence. She also sees why her daughter advocates for women imams, desegregated mosques, translation of the texts in all languages, and reform in Islam. She will not stretch her understanding beyond this and we stop short of my stance on the hijab; the teaching of evolution in academic institutions; rediscovering and distribution of zindiq (heretic) literature like the Mutazalites, Jaddidists and others; and inter-caste, inter-faith marriages. It is an uneasy peace but rather this than the coldness between ourselves. She got a blow from another aspect of sharia when my husband died suddenly at the age of 41; which automatically disinherits my child and me from my husband’s property since my father-in-law is alive. Though I trust his goodwill, my mother in her simple way is relying on the embedded honour culture (shame) that would deter my father-in-law from doing anything against my child’s best interests. I asked her if she wishes all these media, this technology, this connectivity had been there in 1992 when she walked out with two daughters, only their clothes on their backs and their school books after an altercation with our father. Her answer is not an immediate yes, it has come out slowly in months, a long drawn out affirmation. I understand her hesitation because all of our talks are just hindsight – we really don’t know what could or what could not have been, had all this awareness been present in an already insulated, conflict-ridden society still straddling its “unfinished business of Partition”  identity and the pull of the Ummah. But for now, Shaira Bano’s case and its domino effect give us much to bond over, as the national debate rages on. Oh yes! Once reform is tasted there is always thirst for more. Article: Rights Activists champion victims of state neglect
Title: Rights Activists champion victims of state neglect
Author: T K Arun
Description: The arrest of five rights activists by the Pune Police in different parts of the country, and the intervention by the Supreme Court defending the value of dissent and placing the activists in house arrest instead of police remand, have laid the ground for a much needed debate on democracy, security of the State, and rights of vulnerable sections of the population. According to available data, most sections of Indian society have started to converge, in terms of social development — although at varying speeds and starting from varied states of deprivation. Only the tribal population stay outside this process, living for the most part, as victims of development as new mines, new roads, new power and steel plants come up on the land they used to occupy, displacing them to crowded clusters of poverty, debauchery and manifold exploitation. Mainstream political parties have failed to take up their cause, depriving them of the redemptive fruits of competitive democratic politics that have improved the lot of scheduled castes, the minorities and other backward communities. Into that vacuum have stepped the Maoists, who preach violent overthrow of the State as the solution to tribal misery. Extending the security and development reach of the State to tribal areas, implementing the Forest Rights Act in spirit to make tribal communities benefit from the development that takes place on land they have parted with for industrial or township projects to come up — this is the way to address tribal angst. Instead, State focus is on putting down armed Maoists. Ordinary tribal people get caught in the crossfire. Their cause is taken up by activists such as Sudha Bharadwaj and the others arrested. Rights activists are not members of political parties. They do not have organisation or money to back them, and constantly take on heavy odds as they confront local governments and the police. They are vulnerable, placed as they are in the matrix of power, but discharge a vital function of democracy, of subaltern defence against the might of the State. If the relatively disempowered sections of society are repressed when they try to achieve the constitutional guarantee of equality — as dalits tend to be in most parts of the country — we would have not just an unjust society but also a society that breeds resentment, dysfunction and disruption that affects people who have nothing to do with repression or oppression. This is why it is vital to understand public order not as defence of the status quo, but as one that accommodates the coming into being of a just society, reconfiguring existing power relations. The status quo in India is of highly unequal distribution of social, political and economic power. It can’t sustain in a democracy. Attempts by those lower down in the power hierarchy to level things would be resented and resisted by their social superiors. The State machinery is supposed to pursue the constitutional goal of equality, but often gets recruited to the defence of the status quo. India’s multiple identities of religion, region, caste, language, ethnicity, political affiliation and idea of nationhood make for easy division of solidarity for advance of society into sectarian strife that sets democracy back, and reinforces the status quo of unequal power and inequality of opportunity. To navigate the resultant fractures in society, democracy provides the only reliable guide. Ending triple talaq: is it an attack on minority rights, or a call for greater equality for Muslim women? Apply the touchstone of democracy, which is the bedrock of minority rights. Giving men the right to divorce their wives just by pronouncing talaq thrice is wholly unequal and undemocratic. All democratic forces must support its scrapping. Views that run against the grain of popular consensus, whether on the venerability of Atal Bihari Vajpayee, Kashmiri alienation or the glory of ancient India, have led to attacks on their holders, physical and online. Should such view be proscribed, because they give offence and could lead to disturbance of public order? Restricting freedom of speech on the ground of possible threat to public order is a slippery slope. If the threat of violence is enough to impose censorship, someone will always spring up to produce that threat. It is the job of the State to protect freedom of speech by tackling threats to law and order. Where to draw the line is a matter of judgement. But any facile surrender by the administration before threats of violence must be understood as collusion in censorship, and denounced as such. It is in this context the defence of free expression by the Supreme Court has been most welcome. The judiciary can, and should, hold up the norms of democracy, but it cannot, unless we, the people, stand up for them even more vigorously. Article: Modi 2.0 looks set to fulfil poll promises, Covid crisis or not
Title: Modi 2.0 looks set to fulfil poll promises, Covid crisis or not
Author: Swapan Dasgupta
Description: A fortnight ago, unnoticed by the mainstream — or relegated to footnotes — India witnessed a momentous event: the beginning of the construction of the Ram Janmabhoomi temple in Ayodhya. In more normal times the occasion would have dominated the national news and attracted international attention. The agitation for a Ram temple at the “disputed site” in Ayodhya had, after all, preoccupied India since 1990. The movement changed the contours of politics, heralded the rise of the BJP and the corresponding decline of the Congress, and brought the ‘political Hindu’ to the centre stage of public life. For future historians, the Ayodhya movement will be a defining landmark of post-Nehruvian India. For the ruling BJP in particular, the beginning of temple construction would have been a grand backdrop to the commemoration of the first year of Modi 2.0. Although facilitated by a unanimous Supreme Court judgment, there is little doubt that a peaceful resolution of what once appeared an intractable problem — something that many agonised intellectuals had warned would tear India apart — was possible by the Narendra Modi government’s quiet show of political will. A government less sympathetic to the cause and its underlying impulse would definitely have found ways of ensuring the court decision was kept in indefinite abeyance. The issue is significant in view of the other defining features of the Modi government in the 10 months since it secured re-election in May 2019. It is often said that any government in India must rule purposefully in its first 18 months because the rest of its five-year term will invariably be devoted to political firefighting. Although this wasn’t the case with Modi 1.0 which pushed demonetisation, GST and the surgical strike against Pakistan in mid-term and thereafter, there is no doubt that the honeymoon period is ideal to proceed with measures that might otherwise be mired in controversy. Rajiv Gandhi, for example, successfully pushed through with the Punjab, Assam and Mizo peace accords, not to mention the anti-defection legislation, in the first 18 months after his massive election victory in 1984. His subsequent record was a tale of missed opportunities, missteps and damaging controversies. The first 10 months of Modi 2.0 will be remembered for three momentous decisions that were at the heart of the BJP’s alternative vision of India. They were undeniably controversial and were also sledgehammer blows against an older consensus. However, after two consecutive and emphatic election victories, Modi could definitely claim that promises in the election manifesto of the BJP deserved to be viewed as more than items of decoration. First, there was the abrogation of Article 370 and the reorganisation of Jammu and Kashmir — an overdue move that was acclaimed everywhere except in three of the 543 constituencies of India. Secondly, the Act to outlaw the iniquitous custom of Triple Talaq conferred a measure of gender justice on Muslim women. More significantly, it established the principle that personal laws of all communities, without exception, had to be periodically modified keeping in mind contemporary notions of right and wrong. Finally, the much more contested Citizenship (Amendment) Act tied up the remaining loose strands of Partition, particularly in eastern India. Although mistakenly decried as being wilfully exclusionary, it was a decisive step in acknowledging stranded Indians as equal citizens. In his landmark midnight speech to the Constituent Assembly in August 1947, Jawaharlal Nehru had stressed the symbolism of giving expression to “the soul of a nation, long suppressed”. It is doubtful if any other government in living memory has done so much in such a short time to bolster the sense of composite nationhood. Combined with the focussed use of technology to inject order into the country’s ever-growing welfare programmes, the Modi government sought to blend rising living standards with assertive nationalism. Predictably, this mission came into conflict with forces that had a looser and somewhat confederal notion of India’s future. It is impossible at this stage to predict the future course of Modi 2.0 in the aftermath of Covid-19. What is apparent is that the rising graph of economic prosperity that Indians have taken for granted in the past 30 years will plateau in the short term. What isn’t clear so far are the contours of adjustment to the new realities. My understanding is that the vision of Atmanirbhar Bharat set out by Modi will be broadly an extension of the approach set out in the first 10 months of the second term. The advent of Covid will witness improvisation, shifts of gear, but no change in the direction of travel. Article: Priyanka’s purge begins
Title: Priyanka’s purge begins
Author: Sunil Sharan
Description: In a recent public meeting in UP, Priyanka Vadra promised to identify and take to task whose who had not striven whole-heartedly for the Congress’s victory.   She in effect means a purge of the party. But what does a purge mean? This is how Stalin effected his purges. He had spies and informants everywhere. You could not even talk to your own spouse in confidence without the feeling of getting betrayed.   Now Priyanka has no means to find out who worked or not except through a similar network of spies and informants. Congress people must be sharpening their knives to settle scores. Oh, what ill tidings have come the way of this, once grand party.   Priyanka ignores the hulk, sorry, the elephant in the room. Her very own damadG. Before every major election, he starts making noises about entering politics and helping the hoi polloi. But the hoi polloi want to have nothing to do with him. The Gandhi family though wants to have everything to do with him, painting him as a martyr in from of people who refuse to consider him as one.   Senior Owaisi dislikes the Congress. But he’s always quick to point out the uncomfortable truth, that Rahul won from Wayanad because of the constituency’s dominant Muslim population. So does Rahul owe you one, Senior Owaisi? More seriously, it really brings to the fore the Congress’s Hindu stance.   For decades, the Congress has been bashing Hindus. Ghar Wapsi is ok for Muslims, but not for Hindus. Romila Thapar says, aghast, oh what caste will the Muslim reconvert to. Well, Hindus have decided that the Muslim convert can pick the caste of his or her choice.   Love Jihad is ok for Muslims but not for Hindus. Muslims openly practice beti bachao bahu lao, but if a Hindu dare even utter the words, then he’s a rioter. Triple Talaq is a gift for Muslim women but not for Hindus. Islamic terror must be conflated with Hindu terror. Bin Laden and Masood Azhar must have ji as their appellation.   Guess what? If the moderate Hindu ran to Modi’s side in 2014 because of the G scandals, he has stayed there in 2019 because of being constantly bashed by the Congress. Or should I say thrashed?   Muslims can write in international publications that Modi is out to get them, but the moderate Hindu sees these write-ups as a personal affront. The moderate Hindu is out to get nobody. She has lived in peace with her neighbours, of whichever stripe, for centuries. Instead of being praised then, she is being bashed internationally! Such writers may get published in India-scorning media, but they will never earn acceptance in India.   Out of more than 500 parliamentary constituencies, the Congress could only find one — a Muslim majority one in Wayanad — for its chief. The other one of course was Amethi and we know what happened there. Now Aslam Sher Khan wants to be party president. What is he thinking? Does he want to complete the Congress’s Muslim makeover?   Sonia Gandhi may have won from Rae Bareli, but that was an isolated, even pyrrhic, victory. All Congress party decisions are made at Sonia Gandhi’s dinner table. But she lost her political nous way back in 2004. 2009 was Manmohan Singh’s victory, and then she made an utter mess of UPA2.   2014 should have sent her into political exile, but didn’t. Nor has 2019. She has only become ever more emboldened to serve as a bulwark for Rahul. Rahul berates the old guard for dynastic fixation, but they in turn look at him and say, aren’t you are principal dynast.   Rahul says that the old guard did not support him in his chowkidar chor hai slogan. That just shows how politically obtuse he is. The Congress scored in the fifties. If the old guard had rallied behind chowkidar chor hai, then it could have been in the twenties. Narendra Modi might have faltered in his first term, but nobody, except Rahul, and a few of his chamchas, believed that he was a chor.   Priyanka reportedly says in a Congress Working Committee meeting that Congress key hathyaarey (Congress’s killers) are seated here. Is she going to launch a purge against the old guard too?   The princelings are all descendants of the old guard too. Scindia. Pilot. Deora. Take the Maharajah of Gwalior for instance. He seems to find favour with Rahul. Rahul winked at his direction once he gave that awkward hug to the PM in Parliament, a hug that left the PM completely befuddled.   Now half of UP was given to Scindia to manage. But Scindia is not even from UP. He’s from MP, where he lost his own seat. If you are going to berate the old guard such as Gehlot and Chidambaram for practicing nepotism, how come you are curry favouring with beneficiaries of nepotism such as Scindia and Pilot.   Scindia was up in Harvard or Yale or wherever just before the election results were announced, attending his son’s graduation. But that’s just it with the princelings. They have the name and the money and the heft to send their kids to Ivy Leagues, whereupon the kids will return to India with their noses up in the air and start lording it over everyone else, with a faux sense of noblesse oblige.   The PM doesn’t have any kids, so he cannot send them to Harvard or Yale, but how many people in the BJP do you see doing the same? The culture of entitlement seeps through the Congress, from the old guards, to the princelings, to their kids.   And once again, Rahul can’t crib. He too made it to Harvard apparently because of papa. It’s another matter altogether that he finished from the nondescript Rollins College in Florida.   For weeks altogether, Rahul is acting as the party chief after having turned in his resignation to mama. She refuses to accept it, he refuses to say a final goodbye. The party is in limbo, a state in which it has been for close to a decade. Let the Priyanka purge begin. At least a few people remember Stalin in Russia with some favour.   But Priyanka, that is not because of his purges. That is because of his role in the Soviet Union’s victory in the second world war. For everyone loves a winner. Just ask Modi. Facebook Twitter Linkedin Email Top Comment prasad sawant 649 days ago First of all this is not the century old Congress. They should actually take responsibility for poverty in India versus the richness of Damadji, Chidambaran etc. They should take responsibility for the Sikh massacre and help send Jagdish Tytler and Kamalnath to jail. They should take responsibility for the humiliation of the Prime Minister Of India, Dr Manmohan Singh for 10 years. There are many such issues that lay at the door of the Gandhis, Downfall of Congress is the lowest in order. It was to happen sooner or later as you cannot fool all people all the time.... Article: A law to outlaw triple talaq was necessary, but it could have been a civil offence
Title: A law to outlaw triple talaq was necessary, but it could have been a civil offence
Author: Jiby J Kattakayam
Description: It is unfortunate that the passage of the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Bill 2019 took the course of criminalising triple talaq and restricting itself only to triple talaq. With such a high sounding name, the legislation could also have gone the whole hog and taken on other evils like nikah halala, polygamy, and even abandonment of wives. Of course, legislating on abandonment would have opened a can of worms. Abandoned wives in the Hindu community and other religious groups would also have demanded parity. Though Supreme Court outlawed triple talaq, it did not have a deterrent effect. Cases of triple talaq continued to be reported.  So government decided to push for a law and rightly so, but in creating penal offences the effect may be counterproductive. By prescribing imprisonment of up to three years for a husband uttering triple talaq a marital dispute, better dealt with on the civil side, becomes a criminal offence. The chances of saving the marriage or a separation and divorce on amiable terms are diminished in this scenario. Making it a non-bailable offence can also worsen the situation. The question of who will provide the subsistence allowance if the husband is in jail and unable to work also arises. Further, when a marriage fails this could set a new precedent where government now starts imprisoning all husbands. Government should limit itself in these marital discord to offering mediation facilities, securing an orderly divorce and the best terms for the wife and children. Another option the government could have considered was to treat triple talaq as domestic violence and implement the provisions of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act 2005 in such cases. The PWDVA was a progressive legislation under which women who complain of domestic violence can get protection orders, rights to residence and monetary relief including maintenance. The PWDVA would lend itself very well to victims of triple talaq but unfortunately this has been overlooked. If the Bill gets enacted and its contradictions are challenged, perhaps Supreme Court could point the Centre in the direction of this law.   Facebook Twitter Linkedin Email Top Comment Gaana User 609 days ago Bigamy is a criminal offence for all religions except Muslims in India and there is a jail term upto 7 years. Article: A good day for women in India – Centre finally opposes triple talaq in Supreme Court
Title: A good day for women in India – Centre finally opposes triple talaq in Supreme Court
Author: Renuka Bisht
Description: In her plaint to the Supreme Court against triple talaq, Shayara Bano eloquently describes its injustices, where women “have their hands tied while the guillotine of divorce dangles perpetually ready to drop at the whims of their husbands who enjoy undisputed power.” Yesterday, responding to the Supreme Court’s notice on a clutch of petitions on the matter, the Centre spoke clearly and strongly against triple talaq, nikah halala and polygamy: “Gender equality and dignity of women are non-negotiable overarching constitutional values and can brook no compromise.” There had been concerns that the matter would be muddled by a simultaneous push for a Uniform Civil Code, where the BJP led government would be suspected of baiting Muslims rather than championing women. But the Centre stayed focused on women’s constitutional rights to equality. As the TOI edit page has often emphasized, triple talaq has been banned in many countries like Pakistan where Islam is the state religion, plus polygamy is prohibited in many Muslim-majority countries like Turkey. It really is mind-boggling then that that these terribly sexist laws continue to trump women’s constitutional right to equality in our secular country, despite the fact that even their religious credibility is widely contested. How can India move forward trapped in a patriarchal time warp? Article: Break the stalemate: Here’s how a Uniform Civil Code can be introduced without coercing minorities
Title: Break the stalemate: Here’s how a Uniform Civil Code can be introduced without coercing minorities
Author: Madhu Purnima Kishwar
Description: Given the unequivocal stand of the Narendra Modi government in its submissions to the apex court, it is very likely that the Supreme Court will outlaw triple talaq. However, this will not bring BJP any closer to its manifesto promise of introducing the Uniform Civil Code (UCC). Most people rooting for enactment of UCC are under the mistaken impression that only Muslims and Christians follow their customary or religiously ordained laws. There are countless examples to establish that customary practices have not vanished among Hindus, despite countless reforms introduced since the 1950s codification of laws. Hindus by and large continue following customary practices prevalent among their respective castes, sects and communities even though laws enacted by the state for the Hindu community have been totally secularised. For instance, most Hindu groups avoid intra-gotra marriage because they consider people belonging to the same gotra as sharing a brother-sister bond. Therefore, sagotra marriage is treated as bad as incest even though there is no bar on sagotra marriages in the Hindu Marriage Act. It defies comprehension why the supposedly progressive Nehru government chose to institutionalise the practice of India’s secular courts doling out justice as per religious laws of different communities, even though Article 44 of the Directive Principles of state policy in the Indian Constitution clearly mandates that “the state shall endeavour to secure for all citizens a Uniform Civil Code throughout the territory of India.” It is equally puzzling that those who defend the divine sanctity of Muslim Personal Law have willingly submitted to adjudication by India’s secular courts where non-Muslim judges unfamiliar with the intricacies of Islamic law and zero knowledge of Arabic decide matters ostensibly based on Sharia and Quran. It’s as good as having IAS officers manage the affairs of mosques and deliver Friday sermons or lead Eid prayers. Today even raising this issue threatens to tear asunder the Indian polity because all self-styled secular parties have tarred this constitutional promise as part of BJP’s Hindutva project. Hence the virulent stalemate over UCC. But the solution to this contentious problem is actually quite simple. I present below a proposal i had offered in 1985 soon after the furore that broke out with the Supreme Court judgment in Shah Bano case. It has the potential to break the stalemate on UCC without either coercing Muslims and Christians into reform or compromising the constitutional promise of equal citizenship rights to all. Its points can be summarised as follows: India’s secular courts should stop adjudicating disputes on the basis of personal laws of any community – be it Hindu, Muslim, Christian or Parsi. Instead, the state should confine itself to adjudicating cases only under the existing secular laws such as the Indian Marriage Act, Indian Divorce Act, Indian Succession Act, Indian Wards & Guardianship Act. These should be applicable to all citizens that choose to approach secular courts, irrespective of caste, creed, gender or religion. But these laws need to be carefully reviewed and improved in order to make them egalitarian and gender just. Those who wish to continue with religio-customary practices of their community should be free to do so provided they don’t expect India’s secular law courts to be saddled with the burden of adjudication and enforcement. Let the onus of ensuring compliance with customary laws rest with consensually accepted authority figures of that community – be it the local imam or granthi, the family priest, caste panchayat or the spiritual gurus of the concerned sects. However, if even one party to the family dispute feels dissatisfied with the verdict of the authority adjudicating customary law, he/she should have the right to approach the secular courts where the dispute should be adjudicated only within the framework of secular laws applicable to all. Those who think this amounts to giving a free hand to retrogressive elements among Hindus, Muslims, Christians, Sikhs, Parsis would do well to remember that family laws enacted by the state, including provisions of the Indian Penal Code, come into play only when someone invokes their protection through the police and law courts. For example, the current law against bigamous marriages among Hindus works in favour of only those Hindu women who choose to sue their husbands in a court of law. A Muslim woman who accepts the second or third marriage of her husband or doesn’t legally lodge a complaint after being arbitrarily abandoned is not going to benefit even if the arbitrary triple talaq is declared illegal. This is true not just for India but also for countries that give no legal recognition to Muslim or Hindu Personal Law as India does. There is now concrete evidence that when better options are available neither Muslim nor any other group of women hesitate from availing of them. Today a growing number of Muslim women are filing cases under Dowry Prohibition Act as well as the laws against domestic violence, even though these laws don’t draw legitimacy from the Holy Quran or the Shariat. Neither the All India Muslim Personal Law Board nor any mullah or maulvi has dared openly prohibit Muslim women from doing so. This is because these laws don’t have the word “Hindu” attached to them. Though these community neutral laws have several flaws, they have had the salutary effect of bringing Hindu, Muslim, Christian, Sikh, Buddhist, tribal and non-tribal women on a common platform to fight for what are common problems for women of all communities. Therefore, if we are serious about a UCC, let us do away with laws with a communal tag and let the two systems compete with each other on the basis of voluntary compliance. Article: Section 377: Sooner or later, the government will have to deal with homosexual lives
Title: Section 377: Sooner or later, the government will have to deal with homosexual lives
Author: Economic Times
Description: By Sandip Roy Who’s afraid of the big bad gays, the so-called ‘minuscule fraction’? The government has decided that when it comes to the LGBT (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender) population, discretion might be the better part of valour. When the hearings on the constitutionality of Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) started in the Supreme Court, the government asked for a delay. They wanted more time to file a response to a law that dates back to 1861. The court refused. Then Attorney General K K Venugopal chose not to lead the government response saying, “I had appeared for the curative. I’m told the government’s stand is different, therefore I’m not appearing in that case at all.” Now the government appears to have no stand at all. In an affidavit filed on behalf of the government, an undersecretary in the ministry of home affairs says the Union of India would leave the question of the constitutional validity of Section 377 to the extent it applies to “consensual acts of adults in private” to the “wisdom of this Hon’-ble Court”. After the Supreme Court ruled against instant triple talaq, the government painted itself as the knight in shining armour for Muslim women. BJP MP Meenakshi Lekhi said it was the “political will” of the NDA government that had led to the judgment. The government is betraying no such itch to be seen as the deliverer of acche din to India’s LGBT population. But who knows? If the Supreme Court does strike down Section 377, perhaps they will push to take credit for yet another thing that happened under Prime Minister Narendra Modi ‘after 70 years of Congress inaction’. The problem for GoI is the issue has gone well beyond the ‘minuscule’ LGBT minority. It has become a litmus test of India’s own image of itself, of the kind of liberal democracy it wants to be perceived as. Chest-thumping champions of the government are prone to say ‘Go to Pakistan!’ to anyone who disagrees with them on anything. But they can’t use that time-tested line when it comes to Section 377, since defending that law puts them in company they do not wish to keep: Saudi Arabia, Pakistan, Iran. Not the One to Judge But being too proactive about striking it down might not go down well with their conservative base, and many in their own ranks like BJP Rajya Sabha MP Subramanian Swamy, who wears his homophobia on his Twitter sleeve. Caught in that Catch-22, GoI has decided the safest course is to hide behind the robes of Supreme Court judges and leave Section 377 to them. From an activist point of view, a government that gets out of the way of progress is preferable to a government that tries to scuttle it. But it means all the talk about principle is just hogwash. GoI can’t take a principled stand for or against it. Its only damage control has been to request the court to not rule on anything beyond the question of constitutionality of Section 377 itself. It is terrified that once this closet is cracked open, all kinds of other issues will come tumbling out: marriage, employment discrimination, adoption, etc. It’s almost funny that in its desperation to draw some kind of Lakshman rekha around the issue, the government is basically telling the court: please talk about sex, and nothing but sex. In 1994, then-superintendent of Tihar Jail, Kiran Bedi, refused to allow condoms to be distributed to prisoners. Her logic was that that was tantamount to condoning homosexual sex, which was a criminal offence under the law. She told activists to change the law and then distribute the condoms. That led to the first challenge to Section 377 in court. But in most cases, Section 377 is not the issue. Homophobia, or transphobia, is. If Section 377 is struck down and someone walks into his workplace and announces he is gay, he may still get fired. Getting the government out of the bedroom of consenting adults is only the first step. Whether GoI likes it or not, battles about issues like employment non-discrimination are looming. Homosexual lives are about more than sex. Just like heterosexual lives. Moral, or Science? In a more ideal world, Section 377 should have been junked by Parliament itself. We should not have needed to rely on the generosity of courts to affirm the basic dignity of LGBT Indians. But our politicians on all sides have been singularly missing in action. When Congress MP Shashi Tharoor tried more than once to introduce a private member’s Bill on Section 377, he faced empty Congress benches and jeering BJP members. “Several MPs who had promised to vote in favour absent,” tweeted Tharoor at that time. He faced catcalls and snide remarks about why he needed the Bill. Individual BJP politicians like Arun Jaitley have been LGBT-supportive. BJP spokesperson Shaina N C has even spoken as a chief guest at an LGBT film festival. But when a Subramanian Swamy calls homosexuality a “danger to national security”, they maintain a discreet silence. The battle over Section 377 has shown all of us the difference between a broad chest and a broad mind. Article: End triple talaq divorce: Shayara Bano case will be critical for gender justice to Muslim women
Title: End triple talaq divorce: Shayara Bano case will be critical for gender justice to Muslim women
Author: Zeenat Shaukat Ali
Description: The Supreme Court’s suo motu decision delivered by Chief Justice T S Thakur and Justice U U Lalit, to test the legal validity of triple talaq in one sitting in the petition filed by Shayara Bano, has long been overdue. Shayara Bano – a sociology postgraduate and a mother of two – appealed that triple talaq be declared unconstitutional when her husband ended their 15-year-old marriage by sending her a letter with the word talaq written on it thrice. The All India Muslim Personal Law Board has declared that the country’s top court has no jurisdiction to undertake the exercise as Muslim Personal Law “is inextricably interwoven with the religion of Islam”, being based on the Quran and not on a law enacted by Parliament. This argument has little logic. It needs to be unequivocally stated that the talaq-i-bidat, admitted by the Muslim Personal Law Board to be “sinful” and an “innovation”, finds no sanction in the Quran. Neither does the Quran sanction this form of divorce in one sitting nor was it legally held permissible by the Prophet. Such a practice violates the fundamental principles of gender justice, gender equity, good conscience and the dignity of women strongly enunciated in Islam. The Prophet denounced the pre-Islamic, patriarchal notion of the husband’s absolute right to divorce, stating that divorce was the most reprehensible of all things permitted: “God has not created anything on the face of the earth that he loves more than emancipation; and God has created nothing upon the face of the earth more hateful to him than divorce” (AD 13:3). The Quran illustrates this point by expressing approval when the Prophet recommended that Zayd should not divorce his wife in spite of the fact that there was long standing dissension between husband and wife. “Behold thou should say to one who has received the Grace of God and His favour, retain your wife in wedlock and fear God” (Q 33:37). The arbitrary, undisputed, absolute power of divorce by the husband with triple talaq in a single sitting was the common customary law practised in pre-Islamic Arabia in the days of jahiliyya or ignorance, where a husband would discard his wife by contemptuously tossing his slipper saying “you are unto me like my slipper”. This is a grave distortion of the law of divorce in Islam and was condemned by the Prophet as the following Tradition demonstrates: “The Messenger of Allah was informed of a man (Rukhana) who divorced his wife three times together, his face became red and he stood up in displeasure and said: ‘Is the Book of Allah being sported with while I am still in your midst?’” (NS 27:6) This mode of talaq, once pronounced, is considered “bain” or irrevocable where rights of inheritance cease immediately on pronouncement though the death of the husband or wife may occur during the period of iddat or period of waiting. Further, in this form of talaq, if the parties wish to remarry the wife undergoes halala, a humiliating pre-Islamic practice where the wife went through a marriage with another man which is consummated and subsequently dissolved. As Justice Ameer Ali points out, legitimacy of the triple talaq seems to have crept into Islamic jurisprudence at the instance of the Umayyad monarchs. Inexplicably, although disapproved by the classical jurists, it has been accepted by most Sunni jurists. Unfortunately the legality of this mode of divorce is upheld in India if the husband were to repudiate his wife during her menstrual flow, if he is in a drunken state, in a fit of temper, in jest, at the slip of a tongue, when the woman is pregnant and other such situations, communicated even by means of a telephone call, an SMS, through Facebook or over Skype. Needless to say talaq-i-bidat has devastated the lives of many women and children. Deprived of any opportunity for reconciliation, this mode of divorce has been subject to criticism in several Muslim countries. Modernist interpretation advocated by scholars introduced reform through the juristic means of ijtehad (creative interpretation). Several Muslim countries have brought about reform through codification. Countries like Turkey, Tunisia, Syria, Egypt, Morocco, Iran, Iraq, Malaysia, Indonesia and Pakistan have either reformed the law completely or brought about legally stringent preventive measures in this area. Tunisia brought about reform by de-recognition of the triple talaq within the circumference and perimeter of Islamic law. The time has come for major strides to be taken to bring about reform and change in the Muslim Personal Law in India. In order to accomplish this, codification of the Muslim Personal Law is an imperative. The process of codification of Muslim Law must now be seriously undertaken by a group of legal experts, experienced jurists well versed in the Muslim law, legal experts, liberal ulema and scholars in the field. Gender-just laws must be the common denominator. Alongside Muslim women, Muslim men’s organisations must push for change. If Muslim countries can bring about reform in family laws India must follow suit. In the words of Justice Hidayatullah: “If the lead is coming from Muslim countries, it is hoped that in the course of time the same measures will be applied in India also.” We await the judgment of the Supreme Court, seeking gender justice.
