Article: Hindutva bandwagon revival BJP’s last hope in Uttar Pradesh after note ban squib?
Title: Hindutva bandwagon revival BJP’s last hope in Uttar Pradesh after note ban squib?
Author: Economic Times
Description: By Nilanjan Mukhopadhyay The BJP’s decision to touch home base by releasing a Hindutva-centric manifesto for UP suggests that the party’s intended positive plank centred on two biggest ‘achievements’ of the Modi regime — demonetisation and surgical strikes — has not taken off as expected. The missing rhetoric over demonetisation during Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s election speeches also points to his realisation that the issue is not playing out as centrally as expected. This implies that Modi doesn’t wish to raise the stakes further and run the risk of a possible defeat being painted by the Opposition as rejection of demonetisation, for this would queer the pitch for the rest of his tenure. The people also do not appear to be driven solely by desire to endorse or penalise the BJP for the contentious decision. Clearly, pain and inconvenience caused in the wake of Rs 1,000 and Rs 500 currency notes being scrapped has been neutralised significantly by people inferring that woes of the prosperous were greater. While Modi may have succeeded in getting people to acquiesce to his step, he failed to extract political dividends from the measure. The political objective of replacing the middle classes as the BJP’s core constituency with the masses has not been realised. This offers lessons for those in government —programmes that do not positively impact the lives of people and merely target social and economic adversaries of the poor may elate people temporarily but doesn’t benefit electorally. Consequent to the political narrative not flowing in the direction it was expected to in UP, parties have fallen back on the old tactic of charismatic leaders propped by little but caste arithmetic. Naturally, this has muddled electoral waters greatly. Other factors like track record of parties, promises and candidates’ background become secondary. ‘Jatiya Sameekaran’ (caste alignment), the phrase introduced in the post-Mandal electoral discourse, remains as essential an element as before. Because of this the BJP has little option but to target the old bête noire of the Sangh Parivar — caste fissures in Hindu society which prevents its consolidation for electoral purposes. Founders of the RSS and Hindu nationalist ideologues like VD Savarkar campaigned for social reform in Hindu society, but it was not till the 1970s that programmatic thrust in this direction was imparted. Yet, the Sangh Parivar failed to shed its pro-upper caste public image and it was only in the early 1990s that the BJP embarked on a conscious strategy to draw the OBCs into its fold. On the one hand, this was done by being socially inclusive while filling party positions and distributing tickets. But on the other hand, and more importantly, it united Hindus across castes by raking up majoritarian issues. Riots in Muzaffarnagar provided the opening for an unprecedented polarisation and this has been attempted in UP this time too. The three-pronged revival of the Hindutva campaign — Ram temple, triple talaq and alleged ‘forced’ migration from Muslim dominated areas — is aimed at uniting Hindus across castes. The BJP will hope that polarisation, now appearing underway in western UP, will extend till the eastern extreme of the state — that votes last — and secure it a verdict similar to that in 2014. Clearly, this change of tack has been necessitated by the poll pact between the SP and Congress which forges a formidable social and political coalition. Moreover, tactful marginalisation of the Shivpal Yadav faction in the party has enhanced chances of Akhilesh Yadav neutralising the anti-incumbent vote. The UP CM has also positioned himself as the local variant of ‘development man’ or Vikas Purush displaying wares — expressway, elevated corridors, metro, welfare schemes likes pensions and ambulances, women-specific programmes, schemes for youth — that Modi exhibited as chief minister in Gujarat. Unlike Bihar that witnessed a bipolar contest, the battle in UP remains triangular with small pockets where it is even quadrangular. Consequently, campaign strategy will keep evolving phase to phase as political and social factors keep altering. So far, the BJP has failed to dictate the framework of the polls and after the collapse of its positive platform, revival of the Hindutva bandwagon is possibly its last hope. But this too is easier said than done. Facebook Twitter Linkedin Email Add COMMENT Disclaimer Views expressed above are the author's own. Article: A law blow for a high cause
Title: A law blow for a high cause
Author: Indrajit Hazra
Description: Sometimes, the Dirty Tricks Department of the State can be roped in to do major good. With everyone and their Jai Hinds mobilised — or, in the case of Karan Johar, understandably mortified — into proclaiming their love for their country from rooftops, inside cinemas, under sheets and over the top, let another litmus test of patriotism be quietly rolled out. This test can, inshallah, finally break the viper’s nest that has so far protected itself by having a’Secular’ sign nailed on its door. In a sense, that test has already been operationalised US Navy Seals-in-Abbottabad-style. It comes in the form of a Law Commission questionnaire that wants to know what various “religious groups, social groups, minority groups, NGOs, political parties, civil society initiatives and government agencies” think about the possible implementation of the Uniform Civil Code (UCC). The bangles tell it all The UCC is a long-standing plan — in the mind of its detractors, a cunning plan, at that — by which personal laws based on religious practices and scriptures will get subsumed by the existing law of the land. These personal laws cover marriage, divorce, inheritance, maintenance procedures within communities whether conducted by religion-based bodies (All India Muslim Personal Law Board, AIMPLB) or non-religion-based ones (khap panchayats). Nothing could be more secular than the UCC, a set of laws that apply and protect every Indian irrespective of their identity-marker. And yet, we’ve the strange spectacle of the ‘Left liberal’ being against it and the ‘Hindu right wing’ championing it. What on earth is going on in ‘indoostan? One of the abiding principles by which any debate on ‘secularism’ is largely conducted in this country is knee-jerkism. This is different from, and more insidious than, jerkism, that virulent business of reacting by shouting ‘Hindus are being discriminated against!’ each time Muslims get a discount on TV sets during Eid and by shouting ‘Muslims are being victimised!’ each time Hindus have fun on Dandiya nights. The knee-jerkism against the UCC comes from two knees. One, the tradition of vote-bank politics that has political parties feeding these personal law lobbies and keeping them fat in return for votes. Two, the UCC’s most vocal supporters want it for the wrongest of reasons. Mukul Kesavan in his Secular Common Sense points to how the demand of the common code is conflated with the notion of keeping the minorities in check. He mentions his meeting with an RSS functionary who wholly supports the ‘secular’ notion of the UCC so that Muslim polygamy, responsible in the man’s head for Muslims ‘soon’ overrunning, and running, the country is put to an end. So when the AIMPLB states that “the Modi government is trying to sow the seeds of an internal war and hatred”, the government has to patiently argue its case bearing in mind its own reputation that precedes it in matters ‘secular’ and ‘communal’. But bodies such as the AIMPLB and khaps can’t hide behind the skirt of ‘victimhood’ to perpetrate what are illegal acts ring-fenced by extreme moral relativism. One can’t, for instance, use the genuine history of enforced sterilisation during the Emergency to argue away the benefits of vasectomy. And one can’t certainly call vegetarianism evil just because Adolf Hitler stuck to his sauerkraut and potatoes. The fact that the AIMPLB refuses to engage in a debate on the subject, having rejected the Law Commission questionnaire outright, is a blessing in disguise. It exposes itself — the Left’s rejection of the UCC doesn’t matter except in parlour games —for what it is: a bunch of people holding on to their ghetto power at the cost of their own people, overwhelmingly their women. But it is important that the government — this government — is not seen conflating the UCC with a mission to only ‘save Muslims from Muslims’. On Monday, the wife of kabaddi player Rohit Chillar (a Jat Hindu) killed herself after being harassed by her husband and his family for dowry. Let the UCC also be highlighted as a scourge against dowry. Not too long ago, Union minister for women and child development had said that the “international concept of marital rape” cannot be applied in India because of “a myriad social customs and values, religious beliefs, mindset of the society to treat the marriage as a sacrament”. Well, let the same UCC that will deal with triple talaq and Muslim polygamy also deal with — and be seen dealing with — marital rape, relativism be damned. This isn’t just about balancing Muslim injustice against women with Hindu injustice against women or [fill in your choice of community] injustice against women for politically correct symmetry. It’s about strategically pitching the UCC as a fumigant for the breaking of laws by all communities and religious groupings so as to get it practically implemented. With everyone these days involved in the heady sport of competitive patriotism and all too ready to show that all Indians are utterly one in their love for India, this is the time to strike. If you don’t support the uniform civil code, you’re anti-national. Yes, I know it’s a sneaky way of going about something. Article: Modi government is applied Syama Prasad
Title: Modi government is applied Syama Prasad
Author: Tarun Vijay
Description: It was difficult to hold back tears going through the emotional comments of two Gorkha Bravehearts after getting their domicile certificates of Jammu and Kashmir. The story in TOI said- “Prem Bahadur can barely wipe his tears. The 68-year wait for this ex-serviceman of Gorkha ethnicity to become a J&K citizen is over. His jobless son Robin; a widow Lakshmi, whose husband served in artillery; 3rd gen army man Chaman and 3,500 such Gorkhas opt for J&K domicile.” This couldn’t have happened if there was no Syama Prasad. The revolutionary changes brought by his two most ardent followers Narendra Modi and Amit Shah have changed the scenario from the exclusion of patriotic Indians from Kashmir to their inclusion and assimilation with the honour they deserve. Modi’s Atmnirbhar Bharat, strong replies to the terrorists and strikes on Pakistan, protecting India’s civilisational Hindu heritage with a vigour and clarity it deserves, protecting lives and honour of Hindus, Sikhs,Buddhists from Pakistan and Afghanistan, powering military and giving instant befitting replies to the China, and rejuvenating pride in using Indian languages in place of English – have a definitively Syama Peasad touch. Article 370 gone. Two flag systems buried. 1948’s Hindu refugees from POK given citizenship and a grave injustice eliminated. Triple talaq gone. CAA done. Modi uses Tamil, Bangla , Hindi in his speeches, global discussions from Riyadh to Rio and Shanghai to London. From Kumbh to Kedarnath , Akshardham to Varanasi’s rejuvenation and Ganga Aarti, Hindu spiritualism and civisational heritage was never given such a prominence. It’s like a dream as things happened at such a rapid speed which none could have believed a few years before. Post-Independence, no politician has impacted and directed the destiny of our nation as much as Syama Prasad Mookerjee. What Abraham Lincoln was to the new, rising America, Syama Prasad is to India. In a brief political career, spanning less than two decades, he became an epitome of struggles for protecting the honour and safety of the Hindus, India’s unification, and the battle against colonial and slave mindset. In 1953, he took up the cause of Jammu-Kashmir’s complete merger with the rest of the country, battled for it, led the nation from the front, and died for the cause. In 2019, sixty six years later when India’s Prime Minister and home minister roared in Parliament to announce that Articles 370 and 35A are buried forever and two new Union territories have been created, namely Jammu and Kashmir and Ladakh, it was the day and the moment when Syama Prasad Mookerjee was resurrected. A great warrior to the core, a born democrat, he chose the path of constitutionalism against the forces of the dark ages, the evil empire of the Jinnahs and the Abdullas, who threatened openly to take up the violent path. Syama Prasad finally trounced them with the power of truth and the colours of his sacrifice. I describe Dr Syama Prasad in my book, “The Warrior Democrat” (being presented to PM Modi on July 6) as The Lion who would rewrite the destiny of India. He was a pure-hearted academician who wrote – “My tendencies lay in the shape of educational administration and I did not feel attracted by the noisy and dusty career of a politician. I thought the best way to serve my country would be through the path of Education.” But destiny had other things marked for him. Syama Prasad Mookerjee was an academician, statesman, and a political thinker who redefined nationalism and took up the cause of the persecuted Hindus. He encouraged science education and was a pioneer who went on to become the president of the Mahabodhi Society, Bodhgaya, one of the highest seats of Buddhism in the world. His lasting impact on the political map of India was to remove the hurdles in the way of the final and irrevocable merger of Jammu and Kashmir state with the Indian union and his sacrifice is still shrouded in mystery as many of his party leaders described it as a political killing. Sadly, a probe was never ordered. As it happens with most political stalwarts, their multifaceted life gets overwhelmed by a few more pronounced political events and the other aspects of their life remain lesser known even though those aspects would have thrown a better light on the principal personae of the leader. Syama Prasad is just “Kashmir struggle” for most of the political watchers. My book is an effort to present a wholesome, the real Syama Prasad, a family man, a scholar par excellence, a person who was highly sensitive towards the poor and the downtrodden and the propounder of a scientific mindset amongst the youth. He delivered more than twenty convocation addresses across the country, including Universites of Calcutta, Delhi, Agra, Benares, Mysore and Patna. He was a journalist, an editor and he founded the Nationalist news magazine. His spiritualism took him closer to Sri Aurobindo and he was designated the first vice-chancellor of the Sri Aurobindo University, Pondicherry by the Mother. His compassion and love to help is legendary and the letter of Kazi Nazrul Islam, who went on to become the national poet of Bangladesh, is a testimony to this fact. When all his Muim friends ditched, it was Syama Prasad who came to his help . He was first vice chancellor to begin convocation addresses delivered in Indian languages and the initiative began with Kaviguru Ravindranath Thakur delivering it in Bengali at Syama Prasad’s invitation. That too, was boycotted by Muslim extremist students in Calcutta university to oppose a lotus in university’s insignia as they said “Lotus” is a Hindu symbol unacceptable to us. He was a firebrand orator, a nationally-reputed unapologetic Hindu leader, a favourite of Vinayak Damodar Savarkar and he was also the choice of Mahatma Gandhi to be inducted in independent India’s first Cabinet under Nehru and became India’s first industry minister. After his resignation from the Cabinet on Nehru-Liaqat pact, he was the first choice of RSS Sarsanghchalak (Chief) MS Golwalkar to be nominated as the first president of Bharatiya Janasangh, the party that in its new avatar as Bharartiya Janata party is ruling India today. His contribution and resolve to ensure a complete and an inalienable merger of Jammu & Kashmir with the Indian union, had been guiding and powering innumerable movements, struggle, and political battles both inside Parliament and outside since the last six decades. Finally, Prime Minister Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah did what was considered by many as impossible – by abrogating Constitution’s most controversial clause 370 and 35A, separating J&K from Ladakh and turning both Union territories. Both the leaders dedicated the historic decision to Dr Syama Prasad Mookerjee. That’s Syama Prasad in brief. Incredible Indian statesman, who still remains the prime inspiration to the millions of workers of the nationalist hue whether they are in the BJP, in RSS or in any other organization. Before the infamous Calcutta massacre of the Hindus at the instigation of Jinnah, Dr. Syama Prasad Mookerjee had said in a statement that Jinnah is out to destroy the very soul of India. The Direct Action of the Muslim League was a last straw in the creation of Pakistan. On the massacre of Hindus, Syama Prasad Mookerjee, who was first elected to Bengal legislature on a Congress ticket, wrote, “What happened in Calcutta is perhaps without a parallel in modern history. St. Bartholomew’s Day, of which history records some grim events of murder and butchery, pales into insignificance compared to the brutalities that were committed in the streets, lanes and by-lanes of this first city of British India.” Syama Prasad was an ardent devotee of Sri Aurobindo and hence had unflinching faith in the necessity of a united India. He said, “the dangers in front of us are many; the latest addition in the shape of a movement for Pakistan should not be lightly brushed aside. This preposterous claim must be nipped in the bud by all lovers of Hindusthan.”(Sylhet, 7th April 1940). The Congress remained a silent spectator to the plight of the Hindus. Mookerjee wrote, “Much though we wish that the truth was otherwise, it is no use concealing the fact that the Congress has not succeeded in bringing within its fold any very large number of Moslems. And yet the Congress dare not openly fight for the protection of Hindu interests even though they are deliberately trampled underfoot.”(ibid). Lastly, Congress’s surrender to Jinnah left no choice before the nationalists and Mookerjee supported the partition of Bengal in 1946 as a fait accompli only to prevent the inclusion of its Hindu-majority areas in a Muslim-dominated East Pakistan (If 25% of Muslims could not agree to live in India, how could 44% of Hindus live in Bengal under 54% Muslims?”). He also opposed a failed bid for a united but independent Bengal made in 1947 by Sarat Bose, the brother of Subhas Chandra Bose and Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy, a Bengali Muslim politician. After a partitioned India got Independence, Syama Prasad developed some differences with the Hindu Mahasabha and severed his relations with it on the issue of allowing all Indians to the party and let the Mahasabha become a social platform to take up the cause of the Hindus. At the insistence of Mahatma Gandhi, Syama Prasad was inducted in the first Cabinet of Independent India and Nehru gave him the industry portfolio – which he handled with great finesse and capability. He replaced all European officers in Hindustan Aeronautics Ltd with capable Indians, curtailed wasteful expenses and gave a fillip to the industrialization of a new free India. It needs an entirely separate chapter to describe how meticulously Syama Prasad laid the foundation of India’s industrialization through steel, fertilizer factories and local entrepreneurship. If today Prime Minister Narendra Modi is giving a call to be ‘Atmnirbhar’ and be ‘vocal about local’, the inspiration is certainly the thoughts of Syama Prasad who wanted a self-reliant industrially powerful nation. Meanwhile, the plight of Hindu refugees coming from western and eastern Pakistan was sending shock waves across the country and Syama Prasad was very uncomfortable to see that the Congress was totally insensitive to their cries. In Bengal, it was worse. Like Punjab, there was no exchange of population and property between Hindus and Muslims of Bengal. Syama Parsad felt it is criminal that while the Hindus are suffering and none are coming forward to help them, he remains in the Cabinet and enjoys the fruits of power. Between January to April 1950, more than a million Hindus, belonging to all classes took shelter in Bengal and a section of them also moved to other regions. He remembered having assured Hindus of east Bengal that after the partition, their lives and properties would be protected but saw that it was not happening. He cautioned Nehru many times but felt that Nehru was in no mood to alleviate the sufferings of the Hindus and on the contrary he was going to sign a pact in April with Liaquat Ali, the notoriously anti-Hindu Prime Minister of Pakistan, who was heavily prejudiced against the Hindus. Already serious differences had cropped up between Syama Prasad and Nehru. In 1947, Pakistan attacked Kashmir, in the garb of tribal intruders, grabbed a large part of the territory including Gilgit- Baltistan. Nehru took the Kashmir issue to the United Nations and was seen being guided by a rabidly communal and anti-India Sheikh Abdullah with a strong disdain for the erstwhile Maharaja of Kashmir . Seeing such a situation Syama Prasad decided he couldn’t be part of a government that had miserably failed to protect the Hindus. Syama Prasad was already in touch with the RSS. He had met its founder in Kolkata as early as 1930s and had appreciated the organisation’s work saying RSS constituted “the only silver lining in the cloudy sky of India”. The then Sarsanghchalak, (Chief) of the RSS Shri M.S. Golwalkar (Shri Guruji) was deeply impressed with the dedication to the cause of the Hindus shown by Syama Prasad and his brilliance. When Dr Syama Prasad met him after his resignation, Golwakar discussed the possibility of forming a new political party to voice the pains and sufferings of the millions of nationalists, which was being ignored by a ‘secular’ Congress under its Muslim appeasement policy. Thus, was born the Bharatiya Jana Sangh under the presidentship of Syama Prasad in October 1951. Thousands of RSS workers joined to help the new party that had stalwarts like Atal Bihari Vajpayee and Balraj Madhok as his new colleagues to assist him spread the wings of the new organization all over India. The charisma and popularity of Syama Prasad made Jan Sangh campaign in 1952 elections so strong that almost in every public meeting Nehru used to abuse Jan Sangh – a nascent party and its leader Syama Prasad. Jan Sangh won three seats in Lok Sabha with Syama Prasad winning from the South Calcutta seat. Such strong was the personality and the power of his thoughts, that in spite of being the smallest party in Parliament, Syama Prasad succeeded in organizing the entire opposition consisting of Akali Dal, Hindu Mahasabha, Ganatantra Parishad, etc., into one single parliamentary bloc of opposition called the United National Party with Syama Prasad as its leader in the House. Syama Prasad was the Lion of Parliament. Nehru feared him. When Syama Prasad decided to lead the Kashmir movement from the front there were apprehensions for his life, which unfortunately came true. His mysterious death in Shaikh Abdullah’s jail in Srinagar was termed a conspiracy and a political murder by Atal Bihari Vajpayee. Syama Prasad’s 82-year-old mother Smt Jogmaya Devi wrote to Nehru, who never replied to her letter. The letter must be read by all who say Nehru was a liberal. In fact, Nehru was the most intolerant PM India has ever had. These lines of Jogmaya Devi should shake any sensitive government’s soul. She said – ‘I hold the Kashmir Govt responsible for the death of my son. I accuse your Govt of complicity in the matter’. If several probes can be ordered to investigate the mystery around Netaji Subhash Bose’s final days, it’s about time to institute a thorough investigation into the circumstances that led to Syama Prasad’s death. The giant who created a path of unity and nationalism still lives through his millions of disciples like Modi and Shah who have realized his dreams in less than seven decades of his martyrdom. Several states in the north east have similar restrictions on people from other states settling down, buying property. My personal view is that Indian citizens should have the right to settle in any part of the country, enrich it with their talent, enterprise and hard work. Also that, over time, this would contribute to faster economic development of those parts of the country that prize their exclusivity. However, there should be no compulsion. Almost by definition, anything that adds to a feeling of alienation and angst in the Valley is not good for India.... Article: Monsoon session: Chaos is a byword during monsoons. Don’t make it a byword for Parliament
Title: Monsoon session: Chaos is a byword during monsoons. Don’t make it a byword for Parliament
Author: TOI Edit
Description: Parliament’s monsoon session offers both government and opposition one more opportunity to rise above the din and haze of polarised politics and present some cognitive clarity on major issues facing the country. General elections are still months away but Prime Minister Narendra Modi has already given the impression he is in campaign mode with visits to Uttar Pradesh, Bengal and Rajasthan. Ever since enacting GST last year, government has not displayed the same urgency on its other pending legislative agenda. Even the opposition, despite being offered controversies on a platter like demonetisation or Nirav Modi’s escape, has underperformed in Parliament. The washout of the winter and budget sessions is not helping either side. When presiding officers reject opposition demands, their MPs have chosen the ineffective and dangerous strategy of disrupting house business to make their point. Ruling MPs have been no less provocative. Replacing debate with sloganeering is damaging Parliament’s credibility. Budget session saw disruptions by Congress on Nirav Modi, by TDP and YSRCP on Andhra special status, by TRS on removing 50% cap on reservations, and AIADMK-DMK on Cauvery. Thanks to the cacophony government succeeded in postponing the no-confidence motion. The opportunity to test opposition unity and corner government on lynchings, farm distress, exorbitant fuel taxes and the banking crisis has presented itself again. With unity efforts gaining pace in the states, the monsoon session will test the ability of opposition parties to collaborate in Delhi. As Congress is in no position to challenge the BJP juggernaut singlehandedly, it will need to coordinate with other opposition leaders. BJP must address charges that it has diverted focus to issues peripheral to governance. Government must explain to Parliament the challenges posed by the US-China trade war and trade pressures that are building up, and what it is doing to shore up India’s economic competitiveness in this unfavourable environment. Amendments to Prevention of Corruption Act and Bankruptcy Code and the bill to confiscate properties of absconding economic offenders can help government show it means business. Some pending bills, such as criminalising triple talaq and instituting death penalty for rape of minor girls, are tokenist and counterproductive; they ought to be shot down. The Rajya Sabha deputy chairperson’s post has fallen vacant this session. BJP must soothe misgivings of its NDA partners while opposition must settle confusions over a consensus candidate. Engagement, not disruption, must be Parliament’s mantra.   Facebook Twitter Linkedin Email Top Comment Sachidanand Kabir 983 days ago Why is criminalizing Triple Talaq counterproductive? Article: Female Genital Mutilation: A millennial crime
Title: Female Genital Mutilation: A millennial crime
Author: Lalita Nijhawan
Description: It is commonplace knowledge that Islam preaches circumcision, a form of male genital mutilation as a tenet and a sacrament of Islamic practices however little do people know about the equally practiced female genital mutilation. Under the garb of sacrosanct religious diktats, the Dawoodi Bohra community is obstinate to continue the sublime horror of FGM (Female Genital mutilation) The Bohra high priest vehemently favours this custom, rendering religious justification for its continuation. While in the West, actresses such as Gwyneth Paltrow, Ashley Judd, Jennifer Lawrence, Uma Thurman have actively engaged in the campaign ‘Me too’ A movement against sexual harassment and assault. India is rather taking a snail’s pace in the domain. However, Actress Nusrat Bharucha (Pyar ka panchnama actress) who belongs to the Bohra community and whose mother had undergone FGM has filed a petition and speaks vociferously against the custom. Also known as ‘Haraam ki boti’ in native parlance, it translates to ‘the source of sin’ thereby validating the removal of ‘unwanted skin’. It is believed that partial or total removal of the external female genitalia will enable individual hygiene, coupled with societal stabilization through controlled female sexual act. Clitoral mutilation is carried out in these communities, between infancy and adolescence. But the more odious part is that it is carried out by untrained midwives and self-proclaimed experts from amongst the elders in the community. The usage of instruments such as common knives and blades point out to medical apathy. Looming large over dismal medical procedure is the aftermath of extreme pain, continual bleeding and infections, probable cyst formation, sexual disorders. And it doesn’t stop at that, in severe cases it could lead to childbirth complications, worst comes to worst, even death. It is presumed to take away excessive libido, prevent unpleasant odor, and ironically reduce urinary infection. However there are no medical records to ascertain this claim, much to the contrary, World Health Organization (WHO) along with United Nations International Children’s Emergency Fund (UNICEF), United Nations Population Fund (UNPF) issued a joint statement against the FGM in 1997. In December 2012, United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) came up with a resolution to eliminate FGM from the world. It has designated 6th February as the international day for Zero tolerance for FGM. The sentiment is echoed by United Nations Convention on the Rights of the child (UNCRC) and the UN universal declaration of human rights, of which India is a signatory. In the international arena, FGM is practiced in places such as Africa, South America and the Middle East. In the present day it has been banned in as far as 27 African countries, America, England, France and the general fervor seems to grow. Closer home, a PIL has been filed, intervention applications are sprouting in the Supreme Court. Justice D.Y. Chandrachud has taken cognizance of the clandestine act and regarded it to be a violation of the bodily integrity of the girl child. It was pointed out, why should anyone have the authority to access a girl’s private part, even if it is in the name of faith. When the SC ascertained its stand, deeming it unacceptable, Congress politician and lawyer for the Bohra community, Abhishek Manu Singhvi claimed that the practice is a thousand year old custom, adding on he said that since only a small section of the foreskin is removed, women do not face any complications and it is not any different from male circumcision. He backed the argument with the Right to religious freedom under article 25 as a basic fundamental right. Central government’s attorney general K. K. Venugopal threw light upon the difference in FGM and MGM stating as a matter of fact that while the MGM may have benefits however the FGM must be out and out banned, not only is it futile, in most cases it leads to further irreversible complications. Early in 2016, about 50 FGM survivors launched a month-long campaign in Mumbai ‘Each one reach one’ where experiences and accounts of unfortunate victims are shared on the online portal by women across the world. A number of women have come forward to show their displeasure and cry out against the nefarious act. Since most of the victims are minors due to the age frame within which the act is conducted, it is also a violation of the POCSO act. Earlier this year in February came out the first qualitative study on FGM titled ‘The clitoralhood – a contested sight’ released by Masooma Ranalvi whose network ‘We Speak Out’ is the largest survivor-led movement to end female circumcision. Statistics that stand testimony to the abhorrent practice revealed that near about 75% of all daughters of the study sample were subjected to FGM, 97% remembered the pain inflicted on them, 33% categorically pointed out that the painful memory remained with them much after they grew up. As there are 2 sides to one coin, so there exists a fraction of women in the community The Dawoodi Bohra Women’s association which is crying foul against the elimination of the practice. It is noteworthy however that some women of the community have joined hands in fighting against Triple Talaq, Nikah halala, Polygamy, FGM. But the apathy of politicization of atrocities is a matter of concern. Orthodox members of the Muslim community have made it their manifesto to keep every wrong act alive. And those vouching for Muslim votes are favoring even these wrongs. The SC verdict is eagerly awaited; however a greater challenge than the SC verdict is societal acceptance. In order to see real changes manifest in the society, it is the people’s understanding of human rights, scientific hygiene standards and adjustment of moral compass that need to take the front seat. And bigger than that is the victims’ bravery for they alone have to fight out against the atrocities they are subjected to. They alone need to recognize their rights and fight for them. Article: Ordinance route to triple talaq criminalisation might meet BJP’s political ends but could go haywire in implementation
Title: Ordinance route to triple talaq criminalisation might meet BJP’s political ends but could go haywire in implementation
Author: Quick Edit
Description: Criminalising triple talaq through the ordinance route reveals the political importance of this legislation for BJP. With the Bill facing tough questions in Rajya Sabha, government has chosen to push through its own version rather than grapple with opposition’s amendments. The bypassing of Parliament is unfortunate. The maximum duration of six months the ordinance will be in effect gives BJP ample time to campaign on this legislative ‘achievement’, despite the uncertainty of winning Parliament approval. But laws cannot be solely about scoring brownie points. It must have clarity and meet the purpose it is designed to serve. By allowing only the wife or a close relative to be the complainant, and making allowance for bail the scope for misuse is reduced. Read: Why triple talaq ordinance is better for politics than a bill But there is a fundamental weakness in the ordinance that could manifest when matters come to court and the wife must prove that talaq has been said to her, in the absence of witnesses or documentary evidence. It becomes a case of one person’s word against another’s rendering criminal trials inconclusive, often with the victim securing no redress. Activists have suggested that triple talaq be treated on par with domestic violence attracting the provisions of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act (PWDVA), which primarily offers civil recourse and constant monitoring by the state.     PWDVA ropes in District Protection Officers to issue regular protection orders and represent aggrieved women in court besides allowing magistrates to offer monetary relief. Considering that talaq is essentially divorce performed illegally, PWDVA provisions lend themselves adequately to providing interim relief to women, ensuring their safety, and assuring them of support from civil administration. In contrast, the rough edges of criminal law wielded against family discord may only worsen the situation, especially for children in the marriage. In the rush to criminalise, government appears to have closed out the other options available before it. Article: Good laws make good societies: Unfortunately, we now have a spate of excessive legislation that criminalises ordinary citizens
Title: Good laws make good societies: Unfortunately, we now have a spate of excessive legislation that criminalises ordinary citizens
Author: Rohini Nilekani
Description: The Union Cabinet recently cleared amendments to the Maintenance and Welfare of Parents and Senior Citizens Act, 2007. The amendments, according to reports, expand the list of those responsible for looking after aged family members. Now not just biological children, but also sons-in-law, daughters-in-law, adoptive and stepchildren will be liable. Official caregivers who fail to comply can face a jail term of up to six months, against the current maximum of three months, if these amendments become law. As ordinary citizens, we don’t spend much time reading about and thinking through the creation of new laws or amendments of old ones. We forget that the main constitutional responsibility of the MLAs and MPs that we vote for is law making, and oversight of the executive to implement those laws. During my husband’s 2014 election campaign, I did not hear a single voter mention this aspect of the legislator’s role. Most were concerned with local issues, which they felt helpless to address, and expected the MLA and MP to personally deliver on. Yet, it is good laws that make for the good, functional society that most voters crave. Good laws are fair, do not discriminate against any group and are reasonably implementable. These create the very bedrock, on which samaaj, sarkaar and bazaar can maintain co-operation and peace; be more productive and reach for higher goals. Bad laws, on the other hand, can harass and persecute innocent people; put the burden of proof on the citizen instead of on the accuser or the state; give excessive punishment; and create an atmosphere of fear. They also create opportunities for rent seeking and corruption by putting excessive discriminatory power into the hands of enforcing authorities. Once in a while, as in the Nirbhaya case, the broader middle classes get agitated and rightfully express rage and helplessness. This creates the environment for passing newer, harsher laws or amendments for terrible crimes. Unfortunately, there is little evidence that more severe punishment in the law acts as enough deterrence for future similar crimes. Recent events in Unnao and Hyderabad require us to pause and think, even as we grieve. Societies have debated the severity of punishment for vile acts over millennia, with complex moral arguments on both sides of the question. But citizens and society should pay more attention to the trend of over-criminalisation of common human failings and frailties. Some laws have moved issues from the civil to the criminal domain with severe penalties and jail sentences for non-compliance. This is by no means new. But recent Parliament sessions have been more productive than ever in terms of both attendance and legislation, though there has been very little substantive discussion on the Bills. And this has led to even more policies, bills and laws that fall into this category. Let’s take a few examples, in addition to the proposed amendment on parent welfare. The Banning of Cryptocurrency and Regulation of Official Digital Currency Bill, 2019 proposes up to 10 years in jail for possession and trading in cryptocurrency. Recent amendments to the Motor Vehicles Act include prison terms for certain violations, such as driving an uninsured vehicle. The Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Act, 2019, declares triple talaq a criminal offence, punishable with 3 years’ imprisonment. The Union government recently banned e-cigarettes and now, even just the storage of them can merit a jail term of up to six months for the very first offence. Offences on a private member’s bill to prohibit Paan and Gutka similarly proposed a criminal liability of 10 years’ imprisonment. The Central Goods and Services Tax Act, 2017, introduces greater scope for GST officers to arrest tax evaders and offences are non-bailable if the amount involved exceeds Rs 5 crore. A similar attempt at criminalisation was made for non-compliance of the obligations for Corporate Social Responsibility. Every officer of the company in default could face imprisonment for up to 3 years. That received such a reaction from powerful corporate lobbies that it was withdrawn in a hurry. But not every policy or law has an affected constituency with such a direct line to the government as business does. These are just some examples of a creeping trend that should worry us all. Criminal law may be quite unsuited to address many societal issues. Some of them are about inter-personal obligations and duties, such as the very basic duty to look after your own parents who gave you life. Others affect individuals and create private wrongs and may not require a public law remedy, or may have already a civil law remedy. Equally importantly, if ‘justice delayed is justice denied’, we have to think of the implication of more and more offences that lead to more and more imprisonment. It takes up tremendous resources of the state. Our prison system is already over crowded, with absolutely inhuman conditions. A majority of prisoners are under-trials, which means that their guilt has not yet been proven. None of us would like to be imprisoned without a just verdict. Maybe it is time to reflect and reimagine what issues belong to samaaj to address, however slowly and painfully, and which must fall to the state or sarkaar to uphold. Meanwhile, let’s communicate strongly to our legislators. Let’s hold lawmakers accountable to draft, to pass and to uphold good laws that work for citizens and not against them. Article: What Supreme Court and AIMPLB obviously have in common: Male dominance
Title: What Supreme Court and AIMPLB obviously have in common: Male dominance
Author: Renuka Bisht
Description: After its long campaign for non-interference in Muslim personal law, the All India Muslim Personal Law Board (AIMPLB) is in a quandary now. It will meet in Bhopal on September 10 to formalize future strategy, in response to the Supreme Court striking down instant triple talaq as violative of the fundamental right to equality. This is amidst mounting criticism of its failure to take the leadership on reforming the Muslim community from within. It doesn’t help that the representation of women in the 301-member board is less than 8%. Actually women may have even lesser strength in the executive panel of the board. AIMPLB women members who took a position against triple talaq were reportedly sidelined or shown the door by the male-dominated religious body. Zakia Soman of the Bharatiya Muslim Mahila Andolan, which was one of the six petitioners along with the valiant Shayara Bano, is convinced that AIMPLB itself will grow more sidelined as women become more informed and determined: “We don’t trust them. They have been denying rights granted by the Quran and the Constitution to the Muslim women. If it was indeed relevant, women would not have felt the need to move court.” If women had had greater representation on the AIMPLB board, it would have been more responsive to their concerns. This is a simple enough logic, and interestingly enough it applies as much to the Supreme Court that has put AIMPLB in such a quandary. Not only is only one of the 27 apex court judges today a woman, it has had a grand total of SIX women judges since Independence. The high courts boast 10% women judges, which is quite similar to the 8% women membership of AIMPLB! Justices Rohinton Fali Nariman and Uday Umesh Lalit in setting aside talaq-e-biddat concluded, “This form of talaq is manifestly arbitrary in the sense that the marital tie can be broken capriciously and whimsically by a Muslim man without any attempt at reconciliation so as to save it … It being manifestly arbitrary, we do not find the need to go into the ground of discrimination.” On the TOI edit page today Arghya Sengupta draws attention to this strange hesitation of five male judges of the Supreme Court on a matter critical to the lives of women in India: “It is a telling comment that in a judgment celebrated as a landmark victory for women’s rights, none of the judges find the provision of triple talaq discriminatory against women.” A lady on the bench you can bet would have delved into discrimination. Article: ‘Instant triple talaq is a social disaster … Muslim society wants change but Muslim Personal Law Board biggest hurdle’
Title: ‘Instant triple talaq is a social disaster … Muslim society wants change but Muslim Personal Law Board biggest hurdle’
Author: TOI Q&A
Description: With the All India Muslim Personal Law Board (AIMPLB) opposing the possibility of a Uniform Civil Code (UCC) and boycotting a Law Commission questionnaire exploring its feasibility, Mohammad Afzal, national convener of Muslim Rashtriya Manch (MRM) spoke to Amit Arora, arguing that there will be no religious uproar if the Supreme Court ends triple talaq. MRM says it derives inspiration from RSS, though is not formally linked to it: What is your opinion on triple talaq? Triple talaq is correct but instant triple talaq, which is called Talaq-i-Bid’ah, is the biggest sin in Islam. In the era of Hazrat Umar, a man giving such divorce was punished with 50 lashes. Today, the practice continues but lashes have disappeared. It has become a social disaster. In every three houses, there is at least one divorce. It is even worse in villages. We as a community should think about it. Ulemas should think about it and AIMPLB should also look in the direction of reform. Even if you want to make it legal then have provisions like giving half the property and savings of the husband to the woman. Moreover, except for two sects of Muslims, others don’t accept this kind of talaq. Are they not Muslim? Do you agree with the Union government’s stand that ending triple talaq is about gender justice and should not be linked to UCC and Islam in general? I totally agree. If you link triple talaq to Islam then a thief should lose a hand, a rapist should be half buried in ground and stoned to death, and a murderer should be beheaded publicly in market place. But even when you don’t follow these rules anymore, you remain a Muslim. So, this is not about Islam. Is it now a debate between progressive and regressive elements within Islam? Reforms are a continuous process. Most importantly, it is not a ‘mazhabi arkan’ (one of the basic duties defining a Muslim). Even if you don’t follow duties like observing fasts or five prayers a day rigorously, you don’t cease to be a Muslim. Clearly, it’s just a social custom. Sects like Shias, Bohra, Ahle Aziz don’t follow triple talaq. Your everyday Muslim is not uneducated or ignorant today. For six months the issue has been in news, tell me how many agitations have taken place so far? How many ulemas have come out on the streets? So the society also wants change and AIMPLB is the biggest hurdle in this. The AIMPLB affidavit in the apex court seemed to suggest that men are superior to women and polygamy is good for society. Your views? Women have equal rights. In Islam they also have right to divorce which is called khula. I agree that its procedure is difficult but the norm exists. When i said there should be no instant triple talaq, people from my community started saying that i’m not a Muslim. But can you decide if i am a Muslim or not? Only i decide that. Are you comfortable with the timing of the survey that the Law Commission has put on its website and with the questionnaire? A Muslim woman lives under constant fear and shadow of danger of being rendered homeless suddenly. AIMPLB people are going to mosques and asking for a referendum on the issue. But it’s not a men’s issue. Most men would say they want it. The Law Commission should go to villages. Those who need to answer this question don’t even know what a website is. Let them do a sample survey like a poll, which covers people from all sects and sections and genders. Both AIMPLB and the law panel should do a referendum involving only women. The other half of the population needs to be heard. What are your views on UCC? There are a lot of misapprehensions. When i talk to a normal person in my community about UCC, you know what they say? “They won’t even let us bury our dead, they would force us to burn them. They won’t let us say namaz.” Even those members of AIMPLB who don’t agree with instant triple talaq, like Bohras and Shias, are not speaking against it. This is because they are being told that this is a way to push the UCC. The government should first of all do away with misconceptions. Are you afraid that if Supreme Court bans triple talaq, there could be an outcry similar to what happened after Shah Bano case? There will be some impact but nothing like what happened back then. In Hindus, there were customs like sati and child marriages but laws were made. Hindus reformed their society, their systems. There is a constant need to reform. Facebook Twitter Linkedin Email Top Comment Nabarun Dey 1602 days ago sixth century and twenty-first century are poles apart in all sense. Article: A week of utmost happiness
Title: A week of utmost happiness
Author: Pritish Nandy
Description: Three court judgments made history last week. In a fourth case, in Maharashtra, the State accused a highly respected High Court judge of bias and demanded that a case be removed from his bench. The Chief Justice did it. But the bar associations and public opinion forced that decision to be revoked. And the Government had to eat its words. But first, the judgments. The first judgment came on Tuesday. When it set aside the practice of instant triple talaq saying it violated Articles 14 and 21 of the Constitution, everyone was thrilled. Muslim women finally regained their dignity. Instant triple talaq was always known to be a bad idea and even the Muslims knew it. Most men were embarrassed about it. Women hated it. But since the maulvis claimed (incorrectly, as we suspected all along) that it was an intrinsic part of the faith not many were eager to challenge it. Emboldened by this, some took advantage of it. So you had husbands divorcing wives through speed post, sms, emails, and even over Skype and WhatsApp– and then disappearing or remarrying. The divorced wife got nothing—apart from social opprobrium. Slowly the victims gathered the courage to fight back. It helped that many Muslim majority nations across the world (including our neighbours Pakistan and Bangladesh) have abolished the practice. It also helped that informed Muslims pointed out that nowhere in the Koran is instant triple talaq ever mentioned as a way divorce ought to be conducted; nor is it recommended as a religious practice apt for good Muslims. A women’s group and a few victims, mostly poor and unsupported, finally reached the courts and, to everyone’s surprise, it went all the way up to the Supreme Court and won a verdict that has the overwhelming support of women all over India—and no, it did not offend the Muslim community at large. Stopping instant triple talaq, everyone felt, was a step in the right direction. As indeed banning  sati was in 1829. The next judgment came on Wednesday. It was even more important because it involved not just women of one community. It involved us all. A nine member Supreme Court bench, in its infinite wisdom, restored to every Indian the right to privacy– as a fundamental right intrinsic to our life and liberty enshrined in Article 21 and all the Government’s men and their fancy arguments could not persuade a single judge among those nine to see it otherwise. Many have called it one of the finest judgments ever, where the case for privacy has been brilliantly argued and upheld. 70 years after Independence, when our privacy was under the biggest threat, the court reaffirmed that whatever excuse the government may offer, they cannot impinge upon our private space. We cannot have mobs invade our homes, raid our larders, lynch people. In fact, the State should not be deciding what we eat, what we read, the language we speak, what we watch in the movies, what we wear to school or college, how we worship, who we fall in love with, who we marry. Hopefully, some recent decisions will now come under scrutiny and the Orwellian world being built around the premise of the Aadhar card, the Nandan Nilekani authored script for mass surveillance, will be subjected to review. The third judgment was on Friday. By a CBI court that sent a hairy and rapacious self styled godman with close links to the regime to jail on the charge of raping two of his female devotees. The courage of those women who pursued justice in the face of intimidation and the grit of a local journalist who was later murdered for breaking the story, finally paid off when Judge Jagdeep Singh sent the accused godman, Gurmeet Singh to jail to await his punishment. Predictably, and right under the nose of an indolent Government, his private army went on a rampage. Many were killed; hundreds, wounded. Enraged public opinion finally forced the State to call in the army. The rapist is now behind bars, sentenced to 20 years RI and the mayhem caused will have to be paid for by his Dera, the judge has ordered. The judgment has been widely acclaimed. Now demands have been raised that two other godmen incarcerated for similar crimes be swiftly tried. It will hopefully rid us of a pernicious bunch of criminals masquerading as men of god. Their power comes from political patronage. And now: the footnote. The Maharashtra Government went to the High Court last week, demanding the noise pollution cases being heard by Justice Abhay Oka, one of our most upright judges, be taken away from him because he was biased. Biased? Biased against what? Noise pollution? Is that a bad thing to be? The State proudly proclaimed it had amended the rules and shut down all silent zones in the city. Now why would any self respecting Government do that? Mumbai leads the top noise polluted cities in the world. Fortunately, the bar associations went up in arms. So did the media, the public. So strong was the resistance that quietly on Monday the cases were returned to Justice Oka. The Government was forced to apologise. The judge now wants the apology in the form of a signed affidavit. Yet another victory for public opinion. Yes, it was, indeed, a week of utmost happiness. Article: ‘We will give recommendations on how to change family laws covering all religions … examining legalising gambling’
Title: ‘We will give recommendations on how to change family laws covering all religions … examining legalising gambling’
Author: TOI Q&A
Description: Law Commission of India chairman Justice BS Chauhan, a former judge of the Supreme Court, says his report on the uniform civil code will cover marriage laws of all religions and is not restricted to sharia. In a discussion with Pradeep Thakur he also shares his view on friction between judiciary and legislature:   With government proposing a law on triple talaq, is it not time for Law Commission to submit its report on UCC? We are preparing a report on the uniform civil code. This is too big a subject and we will give our recommendations on how to change family laws, covering all religions. It will not be limited to sharia; we will make suggestions for appropriate changes in all marriage laws whether they relate to Hindus, Parsis, Christians or Muslims. The report will take time as we are going into details of all marriage laws in the country and consulting all stakeholders. What areas of legal reforms is the Law Commission currently working on? We are examining the issue of legalising gambling and betting and whether the Board of Control for Cricket in India should be brought under the purview of the Right to Information Act. The reforms needed in the family laws is another issue we are working on. The first two issues were referred to us by Supreme Court and we will soon submit our recommendations. Government has said it will bring a bill to ban instant triple talaq. What are your views? The Supreme Court order on the triple talaq is a binding order on everybody. Instant talaq is void ab initio and cannot be given effect to. The government can simply say (through legislation) what can be the consequences if someone violates this law and what remedies are available for aggrieved persons. The government has not consulted us on bringing any amendments to ban triple talaq. On the occasion of National Law Day there was an attack on judiciary from ministers for lack of accountability. How do you see this? It was not an attack on the judiciary. In a democracy everyone has the right to express himself. This is a sign of a mature democracy. It is also a means of check and balance. It should not be seen as an accusation coming from ministers. They have more sense of responsibility, and it is just that in their view they think the courts were exceeding their jurisdiction. Has the judiciary sometimes stepped into policy arenas, as suggested by ministers? Courts are always conscious and aware of their limitations and the principle of self-restraint. No one would like to encroach on other’s territory. Do you see conflict between the judiciary and legislature affecting the justice delivery system? Apparently, it may look like that, but in reality it is not so as there is no real conflict between the two. It (the recent exchanges) should not be taken otherwise, rather it shows that the Indian democracy is much more mature and vibrant than it seems. Do you think the collegium system of appointing judges is necessary for the independence of judiciary? If you look at the Supreme Court judgment on the National Judicial Appointments Commission, the constitution bench itself had said that the collegium system is not perfect and requires improvement. The memorandum of procedure as suggested by the bench, providing guidelines for appointment of judges, is yet to be finalised. It is important to bring in more transparency in appointments. NJAC with some modifications, by incorporating suggestions made in the judgment, could have been a better solution and would also have protected the judiciary’s independence. However, it is still a matter of discussion by all the stakeholders and they should factor in transparency and accountability. Why has the judiciary not been able to fix unlimited adjournments in courts despite a law being there? Earlier, there was no such practice of (unlimited) adjournments, at least in Supreme Court. It is a new development which should be resolved through negotiations between the Bar and the bench. There are still some benches in Supreme Court where adjournment is generally not granted. In the lower courts, because there are large number of cases listed before a judge everyday which cannot be decided that day, the courts are liberal in granting adjournments in spite of amendments made in the civil procedure code (restricting adjournments to a maximum of three in exceptional cases). The case management system in courts has to be evolved so that only a limited number of cases are listed before a judge on a given day. Article: Naked Majoritarianism: Amit Shah’s Sabarimala comments set a dangerous precedent
Title: Naked Majoritarianism: Amit Shah’s Sabarimala comments set a dangerous precedent
Author: Rudroneel Ghosh
Description: BJP president Amit Shah’s comment with regard to the Sabarimala protests following Supreme Court’s verdict allowing entry of women of all ages to the shrine that courts should give orders that can be implemented is highly problematic. Shah further said that courts should not give orders that work to break the faith of the people. If Shah’s comments are to be taken at face value, then they clearly constitute a majoritarian agenda. There are two aspects to Shah’s remarks. First, in asking for implementable orders, Shah is basically saying that orders that are perceived to be against the majority faith/tradition won’t be respected. Not only does this fly in the face of the Supreme Court’s authority, it sets a dangerous precedent whereby a majority formation can reject judicial injunctions. And if courts were to give judgments keeping in mind perceived majority wishes then they wouldn’t need to exist at all. One could simply follow so-called majority traditions and sentiments – which themselves can be constructed by vested political interests – to decide matters. Similarly, to ask courts to refrain from giving orders that offend the faith of a community is again incongruent with our constitutional scheme. While the constitution guarantees freedom of religion, it also gives equal weightage to secularism and equality. Besides, if Shah and BJP can be welcoming of Supreme Court’s judgment striking down the Muslim practice of triple talaq, then how can they oppose the judgment of the same court that lifted the ban on entry of women (10-50 years) to Sabarimala? In both cases the apex court found that the practices were not essential to their respective religions. Hence, what is sauce for the goose has to be sauce for the gander. BJP’s position on the matter can only mean that it wants Hindu practices and religious sentiments to be held superior to the adjudication of the judiciary. That simply won’t do. At the end of a day, a modern, plural democracy has to play by the rules. And it is the job of the judiciary to enforce the rules and adjudicate disputes in accordance with the Constitution. A political party can’t profess faith in the Constitution when a judgment favours its political agenda and then slam the judiciary when its order seems politically inconvenient. If there are disagreements with a ruling, there is always the option of judicial review. But respect for the authority of the judiciary, especially the Supreme Court, ought to be sacrosanct. In questioning the apex court’s Sabarimala judgment, the BJP president is undermining that judicial authority. This could unravel the constitutional scheme and pave the way for chaos. Article: Stop treating mob justice as people’s will
Title: Stop treating mob justice as people’s will
Author: Indrajit Hazra
Description: Where does ‘the will of the people’ start and ‘mob rule’ end? At one level, Gurmeet Ram Rahim Singh ‘protected’ himself from the law the same way people wielding power – and those seeking it – shield themselves: by sheer popularity. It was this ‘popular mandate’ that lashed out in Panchkula when confronted with the ‘very unpopular’ prospect of their ‘beloved leader’ being sentenced to jail on charges of rape. At another level, and a very heartening one at that, the Dera Sacha Sauda chief ’s protective device of having enough supporters to make their reactions count, for facilitators in political and administrative positions of power, failed. The law did not buckle under ‘popular pressure’ and treat him with kid gloves, as many of us may have silently been afraid of before the sentencing on Friday afternoon: Ram Rahim Singh is now in jail. Popular will work both ways. In the case of the 2012 rape of ‘Nirbahaya’ in Delhi, it was the wave of public mood – anger, desperation, and more anger – that not only ‘pressurised’ the law to act swiftly against the rapists, but it also was responsible for the Indian Penal Code, India Evidence Act, and the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 to be amended via the Criminal Law (Amendment) Ordinance, 2013, to toughen sexual offences laws. Public pressure actually reopened the Jessica Lal murder case in 2006, after the accused, Manu Sharma, along with others had been acquitted by a trial court. India’s middle-classes, notorious till then for being the ‘silent majority’ even in matters that disturbed them, reacted with adequate anger. Manu Sharma’s protection as the son of a wealthy and influential MP from Haryana was no match for popular will. What was popular will in those cases, showed its face as the ‘ugly mob’ in Haryana last weekend. With scores of people dead and property damaged, Ram Sahim Singh’s supporters went berserk at the news of their ‘guru’s’ imprisonment. Denial was followed by angry bewilderment. But this was no candlelight vigil at India Gate, but mob atavism – although emoting the same kind of feeling in their own heads that angry and disappointed ‘good citizens’ had felt when they felt the law of the land letting them down and justice denied. For let there be no doubt that those who went on rampage last weekend, view the jailed Dera Sacha Sauda leader as a victim. It is the same skewed reasoning of condoning practices such as the instantaneous triple talaq as a‘personal law’ of a community – in this case, of a cult – that applied to supporters of Ram Rahim Singh. It isn’t that thousands of his supporters believe him to be innocent of rape; they just believe that his crime doesn’t matter and should be beyond the law by virtue of his status as a ‘godman’. Which is why it mattered so much how the law and order authorities controlled and defanged this mob. Which is also why the Punjab and Haryana High Court firmly stated on Saturday that the Haryana government had “surrendered” to this mob “just to allure the vote bank”. The charge against the Manohar Lal Khattar government is serious not because of the political patronage the Dera chief sought – and got — from the administration, because the cult leader sought and got ‘political support’ across the political spectrum over the years. It is serious because it shows the danger in this country of mixing up ‘the will of the people’ with ‘the wants of a mob’. Perhaps, the imprisonment of the Dera chief itself can be a landmark case for the political classes to realise that no longer can they pass off the screeches of ‘villagers with torches and pitchforks’ as ‘candlelight vigil protesters’. Be sure, India hasn’t seen the last of mob justice yet. One just hopes that this mob justice will no more be delivered. Article: By criminalising triple talaq, the BJP has scored a nifty goal against the opposition
Title: By criminalising triple talaq, the BJP has scored a nifty goal against the opposition
Author: Jug Suraiya
Description: The Congress has accused the BJP of playing ‘political football’ with the contentious issue of triple talaq. The accusation is absolutely right. The BJP has indeed played political football with triple talaq by passing an ordinance making the practice a criminal act. And the political football it has played belongs to the major league class, if not World Cup class, leaving the opposition, most notably the Congress, totally flatfooted. The banning of triple talaq – which has been outlawed in Pakistan since 1961 – has been widely hailed by all those, of all creeds and of both genders, who favour social progress and equality. The legislation on triple talaq was stuck in Parliament because of the opposition, and by using the ordinance route to this regressive practice the BJP has struck a decisive blow for women’s empowerment. The saffron party has managed to project itself as being truly secular, as distinct from the Congress which, after the Shah Bano case, has invited the charge of resorting to vote-bank pseudo-secularism. The argument that by criminalising triple talaq and jailing the offender, the law will leave the affected family without a breadwinner doesn’t hold water. By summarily divorcing his wife through triple talaq the husband has already shown himself to be an undependable provider. In any case, the new law does have the provision of bail for the offender, enabling him to earn a livelihood and provide for his dependents. In the meantime, the opposition, and most of all the Congress, has also played political football with triple talaq. The only difference being that, unlike the BJP, it has scored a same-side goal. Article: Freeze on triple talaq bill means Muslim women stay less equal
Title: Freeze on triple talaq bill means Muslim women stay less equal
Author: Swapan Dasgupta
Description: Unless there is some political miracle in the coming weeks, it is more than likely that the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Bill — better known as the Triple Talaq Bill — will be put into cold storage for the foreseeable future. The BJP may, of course, compromise with the united opposition and agree to a Select Committee of the Rajya Sabha. However, apart from dragging the matter into the monsoon session, even this is unlikely to clear the logjam. The disagreement is not merely about the criminalisation of triple talaq, an iniquitous practice that had the sanction of law until the Supreme Court declared it void last year, and the right of divorced Muslim women to maintenance and custody of minor children. Nominally at least, every political party has paid lip service to the principle of gender justice. Even the argument against criminal proceedings and harsh punishment of those Muslim men who persist with unilateral triple talaq to divorce their wives is couched in compassion for the deserted wife and her children. Never mind the smokescreen, the disagreements are far more fundamental. It almost seems astonishing that no Parliament of independent India has ever thought it fit to modify the laws on which Muslim personal law rests: the Muslim Personal Law (Shariat) Application Act, 1937 and the Dissolution of Muslim Marriages Act, 1939. In 1986, the Rajiv Gandhi government passed the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights upon Divorce) Act that negated the Supreme Court judgment in the Shah Bano case sanctioning alimony to a divorced Muslim woman. It was a retrograde piece of legislation. Independent India has passed innumerable laws that have reinforced the principle of gender justice and overturned customs and practices that were discriminatory towards women. In some recent laws, the stick has actually been bent in the other direction. Tragically, none of these have touched the plight of Muslim women who continue to be governed by laws that were formulated by unrepresentative legislatures of pre-Independence India. It is not that this iniquity was unrecognised. It was with the idea of framing just laws that corresponded to modern citizenship that the Constituent Assembly enacted Article 44: “The state shall endeavour to secure for citizens a uniform civil code throughout the territory of India.” In the debate on the Special Marriage Bill on May 21, 1954, Jawaharlal Nehru told the Lok Sabha about its universal application: “The Bill affects not Hindus only, but is permissive for anybody, but I referred to the Hindu aspect because that aspect comes up before us repeatedly… ” Indeed, in introducing the Bill, the then law minister C C Biswas posited it as a step in the direction of a uniform civil code. The commitment has not been honoured. The subsequent decades witnessed backsliding to such an extent that the demand for Muslim personal law reform and uniform civil code have come to be equated with assaults on secularism. The Nehruvian consensus deemed that the Muslim personal law will be left untouched as long as there is no demand from within the community for reform. As his biographer S Gopal put it, in Nehru’s worldview, “the problem of minorities was basically one for the majority community to handle. The test of success was not what the Hindus thought but how the Muslims and other communities felt.” In practice, this has meant that the ulama, the most organised section of the Muslim community, and its appendage bodies such as the All India Muslim Personal Law Board have invariably got their way. The AIMPLB declared that the Triple Talaq Bill “encroaches upon the fundamental rights of equality and rights set out in Article 25 of the Constitution” and proclaimed its total opposition. It was this threat that prompted all those parties over-reliant on the Muslim vote to close ranks in the Rajya Sabha. There is a presumption among ‘secular’ parties that the Triple Talaq Bill is a Muslim issue and that its non-enactment won’t agitate the majority community and automatically trigger a Hindu consolidation. This may be true. But in one respect this modest bid to force all divorces to go through the judicial route — it does not affect the male bias of the Muslim divorce laws — is a big first step. Apart from indicating that Muslim personal laws can be modified and even reformed if there is political will, it is an attempt to tackle the grim reality of differentiated citizenship. In independent India all citizens are equal but Muslim women are less equal than others. Article: Equality Comes First: Calling triple talaq unconstitutional, Allahabad high court boosts women’s rights
Title: Equality Comes First: Calling triple talaq unconstitutional, Allahabad high court boosts women’s rights
Author: TOI Edit
Description: In a boost to the case against triple talaq, the Allahabad high court has observed that the practice of instant divorce is unconstitutional and violates the rights of Muslim women. The court further emphasised that no personal law board is above the Constitution and hence personal laws of any community cannot claim supremacy over constitutional rights granted to individuals. This is a welcome observation that upholds the principle of equality and gender justice. It will be recalled that the Supreme Court is currently seized with a bunch of petitions challenging the validity of triple talaq and other Islamic practices related to marriage like nikah halala and polygamy. In fact, the central government has already submitted before the apex court its opinion that triple talaq violates the fundamental rights guaranteed by the Constitution and that the issue needs to be considered in light of gender justice and non-discrimination. There’s no denying that the practice of triple talaq in India has taken ridiculous forms with women being divorced through postcards and SMSes. Given that religious orthodoxy insists that only men enjoy the right of divorce, triple talaq leaves Muslim women extremely vulnerable. In such a scenario, the law needs to be on the side of the exploited. Besides, triple talaq as practised by the Muslim community in India isn’t observed in many Muslim-majority nations. In fact, triple talaq has been banned in more than 20 Muslim-majority countries, including Pakistan and Bangladesh. Hence, contrary to the claim of the All India Muslim Personal Law Board, the practice isn’t essential to Islam. Neither does it enjoy universal acceptance since most petitioners against triple talaq are Muslim women. Thus, the Allahabad high court observation should encourage the petitioners and hopefully pave the way for their victory in the Supreme Court. Article: Triple talaq should act as a wake-up call
Title: Triple talaq should act as a wake-up call
Author: K Malikul Azeez
Description: The Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Act, 2019 is being hailed as a landmark move by the ruling party, but the government passing it by criminalising divorce is unacceptable. The Supreme Court observation that the practice of instant triple talaq violates the constitutional rights of Muslim women had produced the desired result of relieving stress of families, but the penalty clause in the act now shows it is not about rectification of flaws in the Muslim family law. It would only further vitiate strained relations between couples. This should act as a wake-up call for the clergy to introspect what went wrong that led to the present predicament. When the bill was introduced in the Lok Sabha last year, office bearers of the Muslim Personal Law Board had a series of meetings with the leaders of political parties and pressured them to vote in the Rajya Sabha according to the wishes of the Muslim community. This time, this line of action was not followed. And Muslim friendly parties showed their true colours under the pressure of the BJP and for the fear of being accused of playing vote bank politics. It all began with the Shah Banu verdict by the Supreme Court in 1985, the AIMPLB-led by Moulana Abul Hasan Ali Nadvi approached Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and wanted a relief. Rajiv Gandhi passed a law to relieve the Muslim community and pleaded with the board to chart out all the clauses of the Muslim family law, such that it could be codified through a parliamentary act, through which all Muslim family disputes could be resolved. Thirty-four years have elapsed, but no action has been taken. The board believes that the Islamic family law does not warrant any further research. Though they agree that triple talaq in one sitting is not mentioned in the Quran and Hadees and it is a ‘bid’at’(innovation), they still followed it. During the trial of the triple talaq case last year, the Supreme Court judge argued that when such a talaq is not permitted in Islam, why the insistence on legalising it. The board counsel replied that it is because it has been in practice for more than 1,000 years. The judge’s argument exposed the poor knowledge and baseless need to follow tradition. The judge further said that any wrong thing practiced for a long time could be termed as ‘right’. AIMPLB is yet to codify a model ‘nikahnama’ (marriage), despite pressure from some of its members. Going by this attitude and by the history of the board, the attribution of Moulana Ahmed Bukhari of Delhi Jama Masjid seems to be credible that the top brass of the board lacks the wisdom of a Momin (mominana firasat). This is an irony that AIMPLB, since its inception in 1973 began the campaign for educating Muslim masses about the correct method of pronouncement of talaq only after the BJP started campaigning against it. The views of great scholars like Tahir Mahmood and Faizan Mustafa were rejected just because they don’t conform to the ulema’s viewpoint on this issue. If only they had been accommodated, the board would not have suffered such a humiliation in court. The board should wake up and start codification of Muslim law by accommodating ‘the other’ viewpoints as well. But the major question is whether the government would accept the proposed amendments.
